headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Lee, congratulations. It was really quite an achievement when you add value like this in the down cycle. Yes, I know it's hard work over the years, but this really is quite phenomenal. But just, I guess, a first question and a follow-up. The first questio
componenttext: Lee, congratulations. It was really quite an achievement when you add value like this in the down cycle. Yes, I know it's hard work over the years, but this really is quite phenomenal. But just, I guess, a first question and a follow-up. The first question is on the infills and density pilots maybe. I know delineation is what you're doing, but as you get to 75%, is there a program in 2015 to test density?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, I'm going to take a moment because I think I spoke -- I want to thank you for your comments on behalf of our team. Our team has worked incredibly hard to reposition the company and this is not the result of waking up one morning and having good
componenttext: So first, I'm going to take a moment because I think I spoke -- I want to thank you for your comments on behalf of our team. Our team has worked incredibly hard to reposition the company and this is not the result of waking up one morning and having good things happen. It's a lot of good hard work by a talented team that I'm fortunate to work with and lead, so thank you for your comments. With regard to infills and density pilots, our team has continued to work, focused on HBP to drill wells, straddling lease lines. We were drilling wells in multiple intervals within the STACK play, and we continue to add other horizons into the test. So I will tell you we'll continue to do that activity. I don't believe that it would be appropriate for us to turn the ship away from the HBP focus and the results and the returns we're delivering today say that we can continue on the path that we're on. I'm excited about getting to that development phase, but we've got plenty of experience in multiple plays today with regard to spacing, so I think we've got a pretty good idea what that plan will look like forward. But we'll continue to work it in with regard to HBP-ing the acreage and over the course of this year and moving into next year, we'll keep you guys apprised of the results. But I think you can look at that map on @NFX and you can see the distribution of wells. I think the team delivered exactly what we told you we were going to do in 2014. And again, our confidence level is very, very high in those plays today.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And my follow-up is, at this stage, Meramec versus Woodford, could you talk to maybe some of the differences between the 2 horizons practically and geologically?
componenttext: Got you, okay. And my follow-up is, at this stage, Meramec versus Woodford, could you talk to maybe some of the differences between the 2 horizons practically and geologically?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Meramec sits on top of the Woodford, separated by carbonate interval gross age. We are testing intervals throughout the Meramec section. I think we've tested like 3 different intervals within that 400- or 500-foot section, and we've continued to
componenttext: Well, the Meramec sits on top of the Woodford, separated by carbonate interval gross age. We are testing intervals throughout the Meramec section. I think we've tested like 3 different intervals within that 400- or 500-foot section, and we've continued to test the Woodford across that acreage position as well as down in the SCOOP, where we've moved out of the wet gas condensate window up into the oil window. So we're very excited about the results that we're seeing. Specific to STACK, we continue to see competitive results between the Meramec and the Woodford and it's not something that we've done at this point to go ahead and segregate. I think that we tested 3 horizons, they all work. We tested the Woodford in multiple locations, it's all working. I think we told you guys originally that we thought there would be 3 to 5 horizons to exploit, and I would say, we're well on our course. And the results we're delivering are in accordance with our plan.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Leo Mariani with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously I appreciate the fact you're taking a conservative tact to start the year. Just wanted to get a sense if we continue to see the cost reductions that you're expecting over the next several months. What relative type of pricing might we see for yo
componenttext: Obviously I appreciate the fact you're taking a conservative tact to start the year. Just wanted to get a sense if we continue to see the cost reductions that you're expecting over the next several months. What relative type of pricing might we see for you guys to accelerate and spend a little bit more? Do we need to get back up to, say, $70 or something before you would decide to spend a little bit more money? Can you just talk through that process?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the keywords in the call, in my mind, are that we've designed a balanced play. And we've got a balanced program for 2015 appropriate for the $55-ish world that we see today. Clearly, as we continue to generate results and hopefully prices im
componenttext: Well, I think the keywords in the call, in my mind, are that we've designed a balanced play. And we've got a balanced program for 2015 appropriate for the $55-ish world that we see today. Clearly, as we continue to generate results and hopefully prices improve, we'll get to a point where we generate incremental cash flow, but we're not going to move away from that balance. I mean we've been chasing balance now for the last 3 years. The market conditions have forced balance. We'll work our way forward in a very prudent manner. Higher prices, higher cash flow, we've got plenty of high return opportunities to invest in, will translate to more activity. Conversely, if we settled into a lower price environment for longer, I think I said earlier that we can navigate several years into the future and await that day when better returns come. Now I'm hoping for the earlier return to a more buoyant oil price, but we're covering the bases and doing the right thing today for tomorrow.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess in your prepared comments you certainly spoke about trying to be opportunistic for potential acquisition opportunities here. Is that largely in Anadarko Basin, where you're focused? And do you think there is significant m
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess in your prepared comments you certainly spoke about trying to be opportunistic for potential acquisition opportunities here. Is that largely in Anadarko Basin, where you're focused? And do you think there is significant more acreage to pick up over there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- what we believe is having lived through multiple cycles, our leadership team environments like this lead to opportunities, and you've got to be in a strong position to capitalize on those opportunities. Clearly, there are other areas
componenttext: Well, I think the -- what we believe is having lived through multiple cycles, our leadership team environments like this lead to opportunities, and you've got to be in a strong position to capitalize on those opportunities. Clearly, there are other areas in the Anadarko Basin that we have an interest in. And I guess we're politely letting everybody out there know that we're in the game. So if opportunities show up there, I promise you Newfield will be in that game.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Rowe with TPH.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Rowe with TPH.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So obviously, you have a lot of growth year-over-year and exit-to-exit out of the Anadarko Basin in 2015 with the majority of the capital going there. So I guess my question is, you had a nice Q4 of '14 with a lot of wells coming online probably sooner th
componenttext: So obviously, you have a lot of growth year-over-year and exit-to-exit out of the Anadarko Basin in 2015 with the majority of the capital going there. So I guess my question is, you had a nice Q4 of '14 with a lot of wells coming online probably sooner than you expected. So can you maybe give us a sense for your anticipated PDP decline for the Anadarko exit-to-exit? And I guess maybe just your level of confidence kind of in that declined number given the flush rate of production you had kind of exiting 2014?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't have that, so I'll protect myself. I don't have an absolute number in place for the rate of decline on the base production. I will tell you that our base production outperformed in 2014. Our base production is constructed off the type curves
componenttext: Well, I don't have that, so I'll protect myself. I don't have an absolute number in place for the rate of decline on the base production. I will tell you that our base production outperformed in 2014. Our base production is constructed off the type curves that we publish. I think our team does an extraordinarily good job in terms of managing. In fact, we have a group of people that are in place just to manage base production, so we did everything we can every day. Performance against type curves has been strong, so our confidence in the production forecast and the growth rate is very, very high. So I'm not concerned about there being any decline rates or anything like that in the base production in Anadarko that aren't fully and completely accounted for in our forecast.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then just one follow-up would be, I guess there's not a whole lot of added detail about the Springer Shale in the presentation, which makes sense given limited operating history. But was wondering if you could just maybe talk a lit
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then just one follow-up would be, I guess there's not a whole lot of added detail about the Springer Shale in the presentation, which makes sense given limited operating history. But was wondering if you could just maybe talk a little bit more about how much capital that asset could attract in 2015 and maybe how it compares kind of to the existing targets that you all are investing capital into in the Woodford and Meramec sections?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would tell you that the Springer play, the results we posted as well as some of our friends in the industry, if you will, Continental notably where we've been in a number of their wells, they've been in a number of our wells have been very, very s
componenttext: Well, I would tell you that the Springer play, the results we posted as well as some of our friends in the industry, if you will, Continental notably where we've been in a number of their wells, they've been in a number of our wells have been very, very strong. I think that translates to really high quality target. Good hydrocarbon rich, good permeability, all the things you like to see. What I was really excited about with the results posted in 2014 is all of those high return, high rate wells were 5,000 footers. So we do plan to allocate CapEx to the Springer as part of our SCOOP development activity in 2015, and we will be testing both 5,000- and 10,000-foot laterals. So I'll keep you apprised as the year unfolds, but we see it as a strong economic target as part of the good news story in Anadarko Basin.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Dan Guffey with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll go next to Dan Guffey with Stifel.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the STACK, wondering how much production history and how much delineation will you need to see before segmenting the Meramec and Woodford intervals? And then also can you remind us how much of your 210,000 net acres in the STACK are prospective for eac
componenttext: In the STACK, wondering how much production history and how much delineation will you need to see before segmenting the Meramec and Woodford intervals? And then also can you remind us how much of your 210,000 net acres in the STACK are prospective for each formation?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, let me make sure I think I might have missed the back part of your question, so you can bring me back there. The first part, as far as how much do we need to see to have confidence in the forecast. I'll remind you and I think it's in the @NFX,
componenttext: All right, let me make sure I think I might have missed the back part of your question, so you can bring me back there. The first part, as far as how much do we need to see to have confidence in the forecast. I'll remind you and I think it's in the @NFX, the first year of drilling out here was late 2011. So we've got developing multi-year production forecasts. We've had really, really strong performance across that period in terms of the actual results versus modeled performance. That would be reservoir simulated model performance. We're upgrading the type curve in today's release, or yesterday's release and today's call, by about 20%. That's a combination of targeting, locating within the section. It's a 700-foot thick overall section and STACK. Top is about 400 or 500 feet is the Meramec and the bottom portion is Woodford. We now have wells throughout that interval. And when you look at the map that's in @NFX, I think you'll be able to conclude that we're delivering good strong results across the horizon and in both intervals. So frankly, as long as the statistical data says that the wells drilled in the play are more alike than different, we'll probably keep it that way. Because it doesn't make any sense for us to have 15 different plays to try to talk to you guys about. We're giving you a type curve that we think represents the play, and I think the results delivered demonstrate that we're doing a good job predicting performance. I expect it'll only get better from here.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess on the back end of the 210,000 net acres, do you think the Woodford and the Meramec are both prospective across all of the acreage? Is that what the data has shown, or is it segmented?
componenttext: And I guess on the back end of the 210,000 net acres, do you think the Woodford and the Meramec are both prospective across all of the acreage? Is that what the data has shown, or is it segmented?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look closely at the map and the @NFX, we actually have outlines and that we've had those outlines of the domain for I guess -- since we announced the play back in August of '13. So there's a Woodford outline and there's a Meramec outline. I'l
componenttext: Well, if you look closely at the map and the @NFX, we actually have outlines and that we've had those outlines of the domain for I guess -- since we announced the play back in August of '13. So there's a Woodford outline and there's a Meramec outline. I'll caution you to say, that the edges are not absolute. But you'll see that we have drilled wells where they overlay one another and we've drilled wells that are outside of the Woodford and only in the Meramec. So you can get some feel for that, looking at the distribution of wells that have been drilled. As if you put a tape down and say, what's 300 square miles look like? It'll cover most of that area up there. And I think the split out on the wells to date, just to give you a feel, so it's not skewed. We've got about 40% of the wells that have been drilled. I think total you can go back and check this tally or get with Steve, I think it's 40% of the wells have been in the Woodford and somewhere around the 60-ish-percent have been in the Meramec to date.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then I guess on my second question, in the @NFX update you guys provided well economics for each of your core areas. And in the SCOOP wet gas window, you're modeling a 5,900-foot lateral versus the extended laterals for every other
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then I guess on my second question, in the @NFX update you guys provided well economics for each of your core areas. And in the SCOOP wet gas window, you're modeling a 5,900-foot lateral versus the extended laterals for every other area. I guess in that wet gas window, are there lease geometry issues or reservoir limitations? Or will you work toward that closer to 9,000-foot lateral in the wet gas?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you move into the wet gas window, you're getting deeper. You kind of reach limitations in terms of rig capacity. We've kind of settled in, in that 6,000, 6,500 and, 5,500 foot is kind of what we've been delivering all the way along the play there
componenttext: Well, as you move into the wet gas window, you're getting deeper. You kind of reach limitations in terms of rig capacity. We've kind of settled in, in that 6,000, 6,500 and, 5,500 foot is kind of what we've been delivering all the way along the play there. So it's a combination of factors, but I think it's mostly mechanical. Gary, you have anything you want to add there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think there is some geology involved but most of it's just the limitation due to depth.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think there is some geology involved but most of it's just the limitation due to depth.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Everywhere we can drill the longer laterals, we're drilling the longer laterals.
componenttext: Everywhere we can drill the longer laterals, we're drilling the longer laterals.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Ipsit Mohanty with GMP Securities.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your 1Q guidance suggests that it's probably flat or a little incremental over 4Q, yet your 4Q '15 over '14 shows a healthy growth of 7%, 8%. I think in your comments you mentioned that you're not grow depth completions towards the back end of the year. S
componenttext: Your 1Q guidance suggests that it's probably flat or a little incremental over 4Q, yet your 4Q '15 over '14 shows a healthy growth of 7%, 8%. I think in your comments you mentioned that you're not grow depth completions towards the back end of the year. So I'm curious how you're seeing -- what is the quarter-over-quarter cadence -- production cadence look like in '15?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what you'll need to do and I think the data is pretty well laid out the team has pulled together, is you contract the domestic U.S. Those are all of our resource plays and you can get a good stable view of what's going on there in terms of activity and
componenttext: So what you'll need to do and I think the data is pretty well laid out the team has pulled together, is you contract the domestic U.S. Those are all of our resource plays and you can get a good stable view of what's going on there in terms of activity and it all fits together. The only noise in the U.S. portfolio would be the timing of pads and things that kind of normal to resource play development. So we'll work through those issues and that's all incorporated in our forecast. The other piece that we touched on is the timing of China. So you get the second half of the year, you got the full impact of China approaching the peak rate of around 30,000 barrels a day around midyear. I think those would be the 2 primary things that you would want to look at. Gary, you have anything you want to add?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we're down in the first quarter relative to the fourth quarter and a lot of that was just timing of completions in the Anadarko Basin. And as you said, we're already -- we're going to be up in the second half over the first half of the year.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we're down in the first quarter relative to the fourth quarter and a lot of that was just timing of completions in the Anadarko Basin. And as you said, we're already -- we're going to be up in the second half over the first half of the year.

componenttext: And then, could you -- you're not drilling in Uinta and Eagle Ford, yet you see -- I see on your some 10 slices on your CapEx pie, in your presentation. Would you care to comment on the capital spend in Uinta and other?

componenttext: Yes, there is capital in those areas and it's really just the wind down of activity. We've been dropping rigs steadily in the first quarter. We have now totally exited the Uinta Basin from activity, and we are about to exit the Eagle Ford.

componenttext: Okay. But then you're not deferring those completions that you've drilled other wells that you've drilled in Uinta and Eagle Ford, you other? It's going to be a part of the production in 1Q '15?

componenttext: We've done the analysis internally and the best -- the thing that makes sense in our portfolio is drill, complete and produce, not delay the production.

componenttext: Wonderful, great. And then my final one, if you could just give us some color on how your China production profile looks like from mid '15 or rather beyond '15. Does it sort of flatline along with the exit rate, or does it grow? If you could talk on that, please?

componenttextpreview: We reach peak rate in midyear 2015. You'll have a plateau period, I don't know how many months that'll last and you'll go on a normal decline. It's a conventional field, horizontal developments and conventional reservoirs.
componenttext: We reach peak rate in midyear 2015. You'll have a plateau period, I don't know how many months that'll last and you'll go on a normal decline. It's a conventional field, horizontal developments and conventional reservoirs.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on a couple of your earlier points. You talked about the opportunity to add to your Anadarko position to further build scale. How much quality acreage in SCOOP and STACK and Springer, do you see it out there and fragmented beyond you
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on a couple of your earlier points. You talked about the opportunity to add to your Anadarko position to further build scale. How much quality acreage in SCOOP and STACK and Springer, do you see it out there and fragmented beyond yourselves and 2 other large players? Or is your focus, as you seem to reference in one of the earlier questions, building a position in more exploratory or step that acreage in other parts of the basin?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just say, Brian, about all we're going to say today is that we're going to be opportunistic. I can promise you we aren't going to chase ran past your acreage to pad counts. But there is attractive acreage out there and there are people that contro
componenttext: I would just say, Brian, about all we're going to say today is that we're going to be opportunistic. I can promise you we aren't going to chase ran past your acreage to pad counts. But there is attractive acreage out there and there are people that control acreage that we view as attractive and -- the market conditions and the timing is right, we'd like to add them to the portfolio. But it'll be within the context of the core plays.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then we saw obviously another very strong quarter in the Anadarko Basin, looking at your guidance, it would appear to imply some slowdown in sequential growth versus your recent quarter trends. Is this Newfield being conservative? Or are
componenttext: Got it, okay. And then we saw obviously another very strong quarter in the Anadarko Basin, looking at your guidance, it would appear to imply some slowdown in sequential growth versus your recent quarter trends. Is this Newfield being conservative? Or are you referenced backlog building here in the first quarter? Can you provide a little bit more specifics on the timing of completions versus perhaps the level of conservatism or your decline rates?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I've touched on it in one of the earlier answers, but most of the variability quarter-to-quarter we've had, it's just the timing of pads. Because we've been doing a lot of pad drilling and that certainly is still going to impact us in terms o
componenttext: Yes. I think I've touched on it in one of the earlier answers, but most of the variability quarter-to-quarter we've had, it's just the timing of pads. Because we've been doing a lot of pad drilling and that certainly is still going to impact us in terms of timing in the Anadarko Basin notably in SCOOP where we've been in development for most of the last 1.5 years or so. I would tell you that beyond that take 40% out of the capital budget, there's a general overall slowdown. But I think Gary and the team have been managing that very well, and we've been dropping rigs over the last several weeks of the timing of China and all this comes together to leave us in real good shape. $1 billion, $1.2 billion, we can tread sideways in the market. So I think that's kind of the way to think that we're sort of at maintenance level, but in the core plays we're growing at a healthy rate. Gary?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing specific to SCOOP and STACK, Brian, I'd add is that in the SCOOP play that's historically been just 1 or 2 wells per pad and we're going to be more pad drilling in STACK. And what you're going to see this year is we're going to make a
componenttext: Yes, the only thing specific to SCOOP and STACK, Brian, I'd add is that in the SCOOP play that's historically been just 1 or 2 wells per pad and we're going to be more pad drilling in STACK. And what you're going to see this year is we're going to make a more -- we'll have a more balanced program between SCOOP and STACK. So the pad drilling, and as we move to STACK, will have a higher oil cut which will make the apparent production growth look slower.

componenttext: Okay, great. I appreciate that clarification. And then just thinking about idling activity in the Uinta and the Eagle Ford, and obviously liquidity isn't an issue, but did those potentially become divestiture assets or targeted for divestiture with the amount of running room you have in the Anadarko Basin?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've demonstrated over the last several years that we've been able to sell assets. I think we've had asset sales at appropriate times in the market. What we have in those other areas are solid core asset positions. I think the Uinta Basin j
componenttext: Well, I think we've demonstrated over the last several years that we've been able to sell assets. I think we've had asset sales at appropriate times in the market. What we have in those other areas are solid core asset positions. I think the Uinta Basin just the horizontal piece of that, so 1 billion barrels of potential. So I'm not going to tell you that things aren't for sale, but we have no plans to sell any of these assets, and I think we've seen and demonstrated the benefits of being able to operate across multiple areas. I think you look closely at the @NFX publication, I'm really impressed with what the team has delivered in STACK and SCOOP and the Williston Basin. And if you look at the percentage gains over time, you'll see an amazing level of consistency there. That tells you that the organization is a learning organization. It's working as a team and frankly first opportunity to go back to work and have those competing in the return space with our other plays, we're going to go back to work in those basins.

componenttext: I think the first place we'd take a look at is balance sheet, make sure the balance sheet remains strong. But as we saw more long-term rally and if they were moving into the $75 to $80 range and it looked like we had stability there, clearly the plays in the Uinta, Williston would get incremental activity.

componenttext: As far as multizone tests, we don't have any specific plans to do any multizone or STACK completions. I mean, if you're thinking about multilaterals in particular. Everything that we drill is mono-bore. We believe in the long lateral SXL. So each one of those laterals will be targeted in a specific horizon. And if there are any other activities related to that, Gary can give you some color.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome, everyone to the Newfield Exploration Second Quarter Conference Call. For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I will turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.
componenttext:
Welcome, everyone to the Newfield Exploration Second Quarter Conference Call. 
For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I will turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on this very early start today. For now, I hope you've have a chance to review our release from last evening and our @NFX, which had a lot of new details on our exciting stag play in the Anadarko Basin. We
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on this very early start today. For now, I hope you've have a chance to review our release from last evening and our @NFX, which had a lot of new details on our exciting stag play in the Anadarko Basin. We plan to reference some of these slides in @NFX, so please have it ready during the discussion. Speakers on our call today include Chairman, Lee Boothby; our COO, Gary Packer; and our CFO, Larry Massaro. We will all be available at the end of the prepared remarks today to answer any of your questions. [Operator Instructions]
Before handing the call over to Lee, let me remind you that this call is being recorded, and it will be available on our websites, along with today's earnings release, accompanying financial tables and other non-definitional measures. Today's discussion will contain forward-looking estimates and assumptions that are based on our current views and our most reasonable expectations. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed this morning. A full disclaimer is provided on our earnings release and our most recent filings with the SEC.
Thanks again for dialing in. And I'll now turn the call over to our Chairman, Lee Boothby.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. We appreciate your interest and investment in our company. We're showing strong results today across the company's portfolio. You'll see in today's @NFX that we met or exceeded our expectations across all of our oper
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. We appreciate your interest and investment in our company. We're showing strong results today across the company's portfolio. You'll see in today's @NFX that we met or exceeded our expectations across all of our operating regions. Although the focus today is on the Anadarko Basin, Team Newfield is doing extremely well. We have markedly lower well cost in the Anadarko and Williston Basin, and we expanded the track record of exceeding production expectations in the Eagle Ford, Williston and Uinta Basins. 
Our teams are looking for innovative ways to lower operating expenses and enhance margins across the business, and our efforts are flowing through our bottom line. We are confident that we have the people and assets in place today to merge stronger more profitable once commodity prices stabilize. Make no doubt about it, these are challenging and volatile times in the E&P business. 
After about 5 years of oil prices in the 90s, coming where today, coming we have oil prices in the 50s and implications of a lower for longer price scenario. We are proactively making strategic decisions to manage our business through today's cycle. The business plan differentiates Newfield today as we focus on 2 primary issues. First, ensuring that our balance sheet remains strong and that we have ample liquidity in place to build shareholder value during today's oil price environment, and to emerge stronger when prices recover. Our hedges provide certainty in our cash flows through early 2017. 
Second, we are high-grading our investments. Today, nearly all of our activity is in the Anadarko Basin. There's a healthy tension between our desire to build inventory in the Anadarko Basin and accelerate STACK development and the need to protect liquidity. Today, we increased our capital budget to $1.4 billion, up $200 million, increase relates to adding about 20,000 net acres to expand our positions in the Anadarko Basin. Our decision to accelerate drilling to hold our acreage and move into full field development. Anadarko Basin is economically resilient and our returns are improving. Our drilling additional 15 wells in 2015, we will offset about $40 million in lease renewal expenses and ensure that 100% of our acreage is HBP by the end of next year.
We believe that our business plan carefully balances these important issues. Financial transactions were executed earlier this year to strengthen our balance sheet and ensure that we have ample liquidity to not only weather a prolonged period of lower oil prices, but also to succeed and and value. 
We will maintain a strong balance sheet. We are focused on maintaining our leverage ratios at or near current levels and we would look to sell other noncore assets as required to preserve our strong balance sheet and liquidity.
Exactly 1 year ago today, we were growing more concerned about the trajectory of oil prices and moved aggressively to strengthen our hedge position. Our peers were founded and our hedges have been instrumental in preserving our cash flow. On mark-to-market at the end of July, our hedge position would add about $490 million in revenue in 2015, and an additional $250 million in 2016. This gives us higher certainty in our future cash flow and we view our hedges as a differentiator amongst our peers.
The corporate development team and the strategic planning teams has done an excellent job of mitigating risk in putting our company in a position of relative strength, and I applaud their efforts.
Over the last 5 years, we took dramatic steps to better focus our portfolio in capital investments. Before the oil price decline last year, we had executed about $2.5 billion in nonstrategic asset sales, and used a large portion of the proceeds to capture and accelerate the development of SCOOP and STACK, and this has paid off. We will continue to consider using sale of additional nonstrategic assets to fund our future acceleration plans.
In early 2015, we quickly cut our capital expenditures to borrow more than 70% of our planned investments in the Anadarko Basin. We are fortunate to have an asset today that warrants investment and provides strong returns in today's oil prices. We clearly see today that our returns in Anadarko Basin continuing to improve.
Even with the backdrop of lower oil prices, we believe it makes sense to further consolidate into 1 of industry's best plays and use our competitive advantage in the Anadarko Basin. Competition for acreage in the STACK region has increased in the face of better drilling results. We are successfully adding late stage leasehold and extensional acreage today. 
With the disconnect between buyer and seller expectations for acquisition opportunities in the region, we view acreage additions as a better value proposition to exploit our distinct operating advantage. Perhaps the drop in oil prices and the realization of oil prices could stay lower for longer will create more reasonable acquisition opportunities for us in the future.
Before we go into the second quarter details, let me quickly summarize what I believe were the key takeaways in today's operations update.
Number one, our well results in STACK are improving. In today's @NFX, we share with you results from an additional 17 STACK wells and continued strong performance from our SCOOP development drilling. To date, we have drilled and completed 46 operated SXL wells in STACK. Two, the rapidly productions delineating our STACK acreage as we push to get it held by production. Wells we have drilled to date are geographically dispersed and we continue to push rigs towards the edges as we align drilling plans with lease requirements. We're encouraged by the consistent and commercial results we are realizing across the acreage.
The acceleration of the STACK allows us to minimize lease renewal cost through higher value drilling investments. The rigs we've added are on a well to well basis, and we have the ability to quickly slow investments if oil prices were to deteriorate our cash flow outlook.
And three, our STACK wells are oil wells. We build our position in STACK in the oil window, and our wells are averaging about 80% black oil in the first 30 days of production. To date, average black oil volumes from our 46 wells are outperforming our tight curve assumptions. 
Slide 11 in at @NFX depicts this outperformance, and supports why our confidence is continuing to grow. Later in our remarks, we'll better explain how the play transitions from wet gas to black oil across the play fairway.
Before, we're testing multiple geologic horizons and this will be a STACK development play. To date, we have successfully tested the Upper and Lower Meramec as well as the Woodford are other perspective zones that we plan to test in the coming months. To date, about 70% of our STACK wells have been drilled and completed in the Meramec Shale.
We're rapidly lowering our well cost in the Anadarko Basin, this is particularly impressive in STACK, but we are not yet in full field development. Recent wells have been drilled in as few as 12 days, and our recent wells are averaging about $7.9 million including facilities. We hope to keep a good portion of these savings even in a rising oil price environment. 
Our well cost today are down about $600,000 from our first quarter update. We know that in development mode, we will easily shave another $1 million or more off the completed well cost. By now, as you simply look at what our team is delivering today in the Williston Basin.
And lastly, we're accelerating activity and the timing to full field development. By year-end, about 60% of our acreage in STACK will be held by production and all of our acreage will be HBP by the end of next year. With this increased activity, we now expect that our fourth quarter production from the Anadarko Basin will average about 71,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net and we expect to deliver strong and economic growth from SCOOP and STACK in 2016. You'll hear more on this topics when Gary provides our operational update a little later. 
I'll now turn the call over to Larry Massaro to summarize our second quarter financial results. Larry?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee, and good morning, everyone. Financially, the second quarter was very solid. We're seeing the combined benefits of lower service costs, learning curve improvements and efficiency gains and our own efforts to reduce expenses and improve margins
componenttext:
Thanks, Lee, and good morning, everyone. Financially, the second quarter was very solid. We're seeing the combined benefits of lower service costs, learning curve improvements and efficiency gains and our own efforts to reduce expenses and improve margins across the business.
Year-to-date, we've invested about $730 million, excluding capitalized interest and internal costs. We expected our investments from the second half of the year will approximate the first half, including about $400 million in the third quarter and $275 million in the fourth quarter. Our capital investment budget for the year is $1.4 billion, up $200 million. The increase is attributable to 20,000 acres in Anadarko Basin, increased drilling activity and faster drilling times.
In terms of production, we extended a healthy streak of beating our projections through solid execution of strong well performance. Our domestic production in the second quarter came in at the upper end of our guidance, despite losing about 200,000 barrels equivalent related to weather and our midstream provider's curtailment in SCOOP.
Total production in the second quarter was 14.1 million barrels equivalent, of which 51% was oil and 65% was liquids. Our domestic production grew about 7% quarter-over-quarter to 12.4 million barrels equivalent. Adjusted for asset sales, this represents year-over-year growth to 13%. More importantly, our domestic liquids production was up 22% year-over-year.
This trend in our production year-to-date has allowed us to raise our full year guidance to 53.5 million to 55 million barrels equivalent. With all the increase attribute to our domestic operations. 
Our domestic production is now expected to be 48.5 million to 50 million barrels equivalent. Discretionary cash flow from operations was $347 million or $2.14 per share, topping consensus estimates.
Adjusted net income for the quarter excluding several one-time items detailed in our earnings release was $0.46 per share. The most significant item was a noncash ceiling test write-down related to the significant drop in oil prices. As a full cost company, this charge was certainly expected and was in line with our recent disclosures in our Form 10-Q. This is a noncash charge and has no impact on our credit facility for our debt covenants. These impairments are a function of full cost accounting and significantly lower commodity price in a 12-month trailing average. 
We have taken both prompt and significant steps to improve our cost structure across the company. In the second quarter, our reoccurring lease operating expenses was well below guidance at $4.60 per BOE. Second quarter LOE was lower than our full year run rate due to the timing of expected expenditures. We again lowered our full year LOE expectation of $5.20 per BOE.
As we noted last quarter, our recent restructuring and headcount reductions will reduce future G&A expense by $40 million a year, and our annual interest expense will drop by about $10 million a year due to lower interest rates associated with our debt refinancing earlier this year.
As we referenced, we are committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and ample liquidity. As we seek to leverage our competitive advantage in the Anadarko Basin and our desire to transition to full field development in STACK later next year, we know we must tailor our investment levels to the oil price environment and our cash flow expectations. 
If oil prices stay in a sub-$50 per barrel range, we will likely reduce our 2016 expenditures to maintenance move levels. We estimate that we could maintain our domestic production levels for about $1 billion. Should prices strengthened to $55 to $60 per barrel, we are capable of strong domestic production growth. Supported by improving rates of return with a capital budget similar to 2015 investment levels. Newfield clearly has high-quality options today.
At the end of the second quarter, there was nothing drawn on our revolver and we had approximately $2 billion of liquidity. We are fortunate to be well hedged with cash flow significantly protected into 2017. 
I'll turn the call over to Gary Packer for the operations update.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. As you know, we're only allocating drilling capital to 2 areas today: the Anadarko and the Williston Basins. But let me give you an update on the Anadarko Basin and share some recent updates from our operations in STACK. In addition to STAC
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. As you know, we're only allocating drilling capital to 2 areas today: the Anadarko and the Williston Basins. But let me give you an update on the Anadarko Basin and share some recent updates from our operations in STACK. In addition to STACK, we continue to see great results from our SCOOP in Springer plays, and look forward to testing other potential geological horizon in the basin over time. 
During the second quarter, we brought online 14 new SCOOP oil wells, including our first SXL well in the Springer Shale. We continue to see good results in the development where we are running 5 rigs today.
Our overall program shifted more heavily to STACK and SCOOP oil, and the results are evident through our high oil cuts. We have 8 rigs running in STACK today. One of our most encouraging data points in today's update relates to our consistency in the STACK wells. 
On Slide 7 in @NFX, we provide 30-day average production rates for 17 new wells stretched across the acreage, which covers more than 300 square miles. We now have 46 SXL wells, of which 32 have been completed in the Meramec Shale.
We are confident that a significant portion of our acreage will be developed with STACK wells in both the Meramec and Woodford. We've drilled 5 pseudo-pilots today to test horizontal and vertical well space, some of which were online for more than 1 year now.
Although early, these pilots are providing encouraging results. Please reference the geologic illustration on Slide 12 in @NFX. To date, we have successfully tested multiple wells in Upper and Lower Meramec as well as the Woodford. We have more than 700 foot of saturated interval across the large portion of our acreage and we have taken whole course towards the acreage to better understand reservoir quality and reservoir thickness. As expected, our STACK results continued to improve, reflecting the rapid advancements we are making in our drilling and completion operations. Our most recent wells have higher 30 and 60-day rates, not all the wells have 90-day production rates yet. In a wellhead basis, oil percentage from these wells average nearly 80% over the first 30 days. We are not surprised by these high oil cuts. In fact, we intentionally capture the oil window in our initial leasing concept. 
Slide 9 is important to understand as you move from the dry gas Cana Field to the north and east across our acreage, the play transitions from a wet gas to a black oil. Note that the 30-day average oil cuts across the acreage. In addition to our first Meramec well, drilled some 4 years ago now, we also had production data for more than 3,000 vertical wells drilled over the last 50 years. These wells comingle production from a multiple horizontals, all sourced by the Woodford. GOR, or gas-oil ratios, we are seeing today are very consistent with historical production data. Our predrill reservoir modeling and our tight curbs. These are well results from our North STACK acreage help validate our encouragement and our GOR assumptions appear to be very sound.
In the first quarter, we introduced Slide 11, which originally just showed our expected oil accums over the first decade of production. Today, we enhanced disclosure by providing you with the actual production through the 46 SXL wells we have drilled to date. You can see that the wells are highly correlative to our type curve. Furthermore, we today provided actual accums on 21 Meramec wells with tighter frac cluster spacing. Some of these wells have now been online for nearly 1 year. Tighter frac cluster spacing is generating significantly higher oil production has now become our norm. We continue to optimize our completion designs. You can see we are making great strides.
Based on our 950,000 barrel of oil equivalent type curve and today's lower cost, our wells are expected to pay out in just 2 years. Our returns are being enhanced by higher oil production early and the significant reductions we're making in well cost. 
These slides, 14 and 15, in @NFX, it's important to understand that more than half of the cost savings we have seen to date are related to efficiencies as demonstrated by reduction in days versus depth, and not simply lower service costs.
Our most recent drill in complete cost in STACK of $7.9 million, down $600,000 from our first quarter average. We frequently participate in wells operated by others and from this data, we know that we're clearly leading the industry in drilling days and cost. Our days to depth are our more recent operated wells have been drilled in as few as 12 base.
The real prize lies in development mode, where we are certain that we will achieve at least another $1 million savings in our completed well cost and our teams are pushing to get us there as soon as possible.
As for other active development plays, let me close with a quick update on the Williston Basin. Our team continues to find innovative ways to improve our margins with faster drilling times, improve efficiencies and optimize completions. Recent SXL wells in the Williston Basin have been drilled in about 14 days, and for an all-in cost with facilities of about $5.5 million. Newfield has a long and proven history of driving learning curves and improving returns in full field development. The Williston is a great example. The -- you can review recent history and see the same trends in the Eagle Ford, the Granite Wash, the Arkoma and the SCOOP. Williston is a great proxy for where we will ultimately be heading in our STACK development.
I'll now turn the call back to Lee for closing remarks.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Gary and his teams are delivering excellent results throughout our operating regions today, and our company is well positioned to excel in today's environment. You can tell from the tone today that we are excited about our recent results i
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Gary and his teams are delivering excellent results throughout our operating regions today, and our company is well positioned to excel in today's environment. 
You can tell from the tone today that we are excited about our recent results in the Anadarko Basin. It's a large scale resource play and we have the people and the operational expertise to continue improving results and enhancing margins. We are focused on the right metrics today. We're executing across the company. We are high-grading our investments, we have effectively managed our risk. We are aggressively attacking cost and expenses and improving margins. We're exploiting our competitive advantage in the Anadarko Basin and we are mindful of our balance sheet and we'll work to maintain a strong liquidity position.
I will close by simply saying Newfield has high-quality options today. To date, we delivered outstanding operating results and we intend to deliver on our full year objectives. 
Yes, these are challenging times, but Newfield is well positioned to continue delivering value to its stockholders today and well into the future. 
Thanks for your investment in our company and we look forward to taking your questions. Operator?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Dave Kistler from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Dave Kistler from Simmons & Company.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: One thing, when I was looking at the forward oil guidance, I was hoping maybe you could dive into this a little bit more. Obviously, implies a trend upwards still for the balance of the year, but that's primarily domestic-oriented with international comin
componenttext: One thing, when I was looking at the forward oil guidance, I was hoping maybe you could dive into this a little bit more. Obviously, implies a trend upwards still for the balance of the year, but that's primarily domestic-oriented with international coming down. Can you just talk about the nuances in those 2 things?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as the relationship, clearly, domestically, we tightened the oil production out in the Anadarko Basin, and you're going to see a significant ramp-up as we look into the third and fourth quarter. We look at international, as far as the cash fl
componenttext: Well, as far as the relationship, clearly, domestically, we tightened the oil production out in the Anadarko Basin, and you're going to see a significant ramp-up as we look into the third and fourth quarter. We look at international, as far as the cash flow that's going to be coming off from that asset, it's rather flat in 2015 and 2016, and then will decline in the future years. As far as production goes, we'll see production down in China about 20% or 25% next year, but we're going to preserve the cash flows just because we'll have a lack of capital spending. So everything is coming in exactly as we had anticipated both domestically and internationally.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, just to clarify, if your question was in regards to this year, the China guidance is unchanged at 5 million barrels. The difference between the second quarter and the third quarter is simply timing of lifts. We had an extra lifting that moved into t
componenttext: Dave, just to clarify, if your question was in regards to this year, the China guidance is unchanged at 5 million barrels. The difference between the second quarter and the third quarter is simply timing of lifts. We had an extra lifting that moved into the second quarter, the daily rate is around 26,000 barrels a day, that's our peak rate from the wells that are on.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that clarification, that's exactly what I was looking for. And then as we think about the low-price environment that we're in, and the continuous loading curve that you guys are climbing rapidly in the Anadarko Basin, can you talk a little bi
componenttext: I appreciate that clarification, that's exactly what I was looking for. And then as we think about the low-price environment that we're in, and the continuous loading curve that you guys are climbing rapidly in the Anadarko Basin, can you talk a little bit about how you balance downspacing, interval testing and completion science in these low-cost environment? Does it make more sense to find areas that holds all the production that you know you're generating strong returns and just pursuing that aggressively? Or is this more sort of balanced approach of testing all these things make more sense? Just if you gave us more clarity on that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start, Dave. If you look at @NFX, we've got dimensions on kind of the acreage footprint. You did a quick math on that, you're talking about an area that's in excess of 1,200 square miles. If you take a look at the phase envelop date there, where we g
componenttext: I'll start, Dave. If you look at @NFX, we've got dimensions on kind of the acreage footprint. You did a quick math on that, you're talking about an area that's in excess of 1,200 square miles. If you take a look at the phase envelop date there, where we got all of the oil yield data, the 80% liquid yield, and we've kind of highlighted where you move from the dry gas into the wet gas kind of say window into our early acreage. Right now, with the drilling results that have been accumulated, driven by Newfield that the addition of some of the -- our friends in the present industry offset operators if you will, you've got a box that's about 30 miles by 50 miles diagonally across that acreage position. Some 1,500 square miles that's been production delineated, and we're talking production delineated with horizontal wells. So it's a large area and it's a large resource. Our focus, first and foremost, HBP the acreage. The acceleration program allows us to finish that process before year end 2016. We will continue to test laterals on either side of lease lines, kind of the paired spacing that information that we've kind of put out to date just makes sense. But it doesn't make sense in our view to move away from the focus on HBP at this point to drill full spacing.

componenttext: Just no need.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The well results have been so amazingly consistent, top to bottom, through the 700-foot thick interval that I"m kind of excited about thinking we'll get into development mode we'll have a fully HBP footprint, and we'll have a couple of miles between produ
componenttext: The well results have been so amazingly consistent, top to bottom, through the 700-foot thick interval that I"m kind of excited about thinking we'll get into development mode we'll have a fully HBP footprint, and we'll have a couple of miles between producing wells, and we'll be able to let the team go in and develop it the right way, right upfront. So we're going to stick to our plan.

componenttext: My first question is about those eastern wells, I guess different IP 30s, how you're thinking of the economics of those wells versus those due west? And if there's any changes there in terms of cost or decline curves. I know it's early, but if there's any completions.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the conclusions are we're excited about those eastern test. You'll recall that this part of the plan exiting 2014 into '15, we're going to expand the footprint. You'll note that there overlay structurally across that acreage footprint that kind of
componenttext: I think the conclusions are we're excited about those eastern test. You'll recall that this part of the plan exiting 2014 into '15, we're going to expand the footprint. You'll note that there overlay structurally across that acreage footprint that kind of give you a picture that on the far eastern edge, northeastern portion of acreage footprint, TVV depths are about 8,000 feet. The western edge, you approach 12,000 feet, so clearly there's a 4,000 foot or so change in elevation from east to west. But as far as the well results, they're very much in line with our expectations, and since the ultimate targets are shallower on the eastern side, we would expect ultimately in development mode that those wells would be cheaper than the wells drilled on the wester side of the acreage. But at this point, I would say very excited and positive and result's in line with expectations.

componenttext: Yes, Subash. There were only 2 wells that we had excluded from the data that we provided disclosure on. Those wells both tested larger stage spacing and cluster spacing. And as a result of that, they achieved rates they're really not representative of what we think our forward plan is. The number that we have in there, those wells produced a 60-day rate of about 625 barrels of oil equivalent per day or about 80% of the tighter spacing well, so still very interesting wells, but we just don't think it represents what our forward plan is.

componenttext: And Subash, I know Gary talked about it in the call, but if we look at Slide 11, the tighter frac clusters, the Meramec are yielding higher than accelerated oil recovery, hence the focus on the tighter cluster spacing. We've founded -- we've proven that that's the way to go on this slide.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we -- you guys, in the past, have done a great job of monetizing your noncore assets over the past few years. With the clear focus on the Anadarko, can you just maybe give an update on where you stand on that process? And kind of where all the moving p
componenttext: So we -- you guys, in the past, have done a great job of monetizing your noncore assets over the past few years. With the clear focus on the Anadarko, can you just maybe give an update on where you stand on that process? And kind of where all the moving pieces fit in?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the steps we took earlier this year, certainly the equity raise, the revolver extension and debt offering that Gary talked about earlier, leave us with $2 billion of liquidity base. So I'd say first and foremost, we don't have any pressing n
componenttext: Well, I think the steps we took earlier this year, certainly the equity raise, the revolver extension and debt offering that Gary talked about earlier, leave us with $2 billion of liquidity base. So I'd say first and foremost, we don't have any pressing needs to sell in the assets today. But I think we've been crystal clear, at least I hope we've been, I'll try to make it crystal clear in response to your question that for nonstrategic assets, it's not a question of if, it's just a question of when. And we know how hard it was to sell $2.5 billion in nonstrategic assets in the $90-world. We have no pressing need to sell it, but certainly, at the right place and time, we would sell nonstrategic assets to further accelerate activity in Anadarko. Just going to record for that statement, but all things being equal, since we don't need to sell, I'd probably prefer to sell something other than a $50 oil price environment.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. I appreciate that. And also I appreciate the commentary around 2016. I just want to make sure, first, that I understand that $55 to $60 is kind of the bogey right now for grow or don't grow. And then, I think you guys are at 10 rigs in the Anadark
componenttext: Got it. I appreciate that. And also I appreciate the commentary around 2016. I just want to make sure, first, that I understand that $55 to $60 is kind of the bogey right now for grow or don't grow. And then, I think you guys are at 10 rigs in the Anadarko last quarter. Can you just maybe give us an update on where you are today? And what lead time you need if you do decide to ramp further.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, look guys, I think at $55 to $60, we're going to have nice growth rates. So I'm not worried about our ability to grow kind of differentially in the industry. When you get to $50 our current oil price environment, we're still going to be in kind of mo
componenttext: Yes, look guys, I think at $55 to $60, we're going to have nice growth rates. So I'm not worried about our ability to grow kind of differentially in the industry. When you get to $50 our current oil price environment, we're still going to be in kind of more of a maintenance mode, but that's still probably will give us some modest growth. So don't look for us at $50 to go flat. We'll also allow have growth in the portfolio the STACK and SCOOP plays are going to continue to drive that.

Let's just say that we're very pleased with the additions and I think it makes good sense that we're able to execute on our clear competitive advantage in the basin.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay, understood. And if I can get a follow-up then, just something that'll -- maybe a little more color on that $7 million level targets at the STACK. Does that just purely represents savings in full development mode? Or does that contemplate any further service cost cuts?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what I said in the call is that hats off to Gary and our operating teams and our management between Gary and operating teams, [indiscernible] a fantastic job. I mean the progress in the Williston Basin, the progress in Anadarko Basin, both in SCOOP and
componenttext: So what I said in the call is that hats off to Gary and our operating teams and our management between Gary and operating teams, [indiscernible] a fantastic job. I mean the progress in the Williston Basin, the progress in Anadarko Basin, both in SCOOP and STACK, industry-leading results. Today, drilling STACK wells in as little as 12 days. You go back and look at the add-in effects and see the progression year-by-year, so these are the best kind of gains largely. They're gains from exceptional teamwork and exceptional talent, driving down the learning curve. So when you talk about experiences in the second quarter, I'll tell you that today, my expectation is $7.5-ish million are probably what we'll see other wells, with [indiscernible] today, we're going to drive those towards $6.5 million. And hopefully, the course of moving to development as we indicated in the call, there's another $1 million-or-so to draw that out of the equation. If you look at the Williston Basin, you can see what we've done there. Gary referenced the Acoma, if you want to go all the way back to Granite Wash, we've done at every place, which is to deploy. These are normal natural progressions that we expect to accrue, and we're running ahead of schedule. At that point, I would tell you that we're very pleased. We've got 7 in the sights, and we're not going to stop there. Gary, do you have any color you want to add?

componenttext: I mean, there's no further service cost reductions baked in into our forecast.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give us a little bit more detail on some of these 18 tests that you guys have in place at this point. And I guess, do you guys feel confident at this point that the Upper and Lower Meramec are distinct reservoirs? And can you maybe
componenttext: I was hoping you could give us a little bit more detail on some of these 18 tests that you guys have in place at this point. And I guess, do you guys feel confident at this point that the Upper and Lower Meramec are distinct reservoirs? And can you maybe talk about some of the different spacing numbers you guys are using for inter-well spacing between the Woodford, Lower and Upper Meramec?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the spacing, remember that we haven't done any full pilots at this point. So the spacing that we've got, we've giving you all that we have. There's -- I think it's a collection of 5 different 2 well pairs that are drilled on either side of lea
componenttext: In terms of the spacing, remember that we haven't done any full pilots at this point. So the spacing that we've got, we've giving you all that we have. There's -- I think it's a collection of 5 different 2 well pairs that are drilled on either side of lease lines. If you go back and you look at these add-in effects in the last publication, all of those are diagrams. What we've done is we located outside of the lease line and we varied spacing and it's as tight as 880 feet, and 880 feet would be kind of 6 wells per horizon. And we've said consistently that we're very, very encouraged with the results that we've seen. It's all we have at this point. We tested multiple levels within the Upper Meramec, multiple levels within the Lower Meramec, and we tested the Woodford. So we've got 3 horizons that are all working very, very nicely. And frankly, beyond that, I'll stick to the story that we told since we announced the playback in 2013. Ultimately, we expect that there'll probably be 3 to 5 horizons exploited in the stack play across the acreage footprint, the other side we'll have those, get it at HBP, and continue to accrue the data, and we'll keep you informed as those things unfold.

componenttext: Yes. Primarily, what you're looking at is continued declines in those basins that we're no longer investing in, both the Uinta Basin and Eagle Ford. And then it's just routine timing of pads and our developments in both SCOOP and STACK.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys have mentioned 70% of your STACK wells have targeted the Meramec. I guess, how should we think about split going forward between the Meramec and the Woodford? And then, I guess, can you discuss any performance differences between the 2 intervals?
componenttext: You guys have mentioned 70% of your STACK wells have targeted the Meramec. I guess, how should we think about split going forward between the Meramec and the Woodford? And then, I guess, can you discuss any performance differences between the 2 intervals?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that there's a slide in @NFX, I don't know if you have a chance to look at that. But you can see how we've kind of distributed the wells to date throughout this section. And 70% in the Meramec, the Meramec's the thicker of the 2 intervals when I t
componenttext: I think that there's a slide in @NFX, I don't know if you have a chance to look at that. But you can see how we've kind of distributed the wells to date throughout this section. And 70% in the Meramec, the Meramec's the thicker of the 2 intervals when I think about Meramec, Woodford in terms of the pairs. So logically speaking, you can almost see 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 type distribution, just happens to be that 70% of the wells to date have been drilled in the Meramec. It was kind of our plan. So we'll continue to work through that progression. I think when we get to the end of HBP-ing the operated footprint out here, we'll probably have some few hundred plus wells that we'll be able to look at as far as the data set. And once we see the finish line for HBP, then we'll be able to start playing out kind of the full development spacing pilots and get the data that we need to really optimize that development. But at this point, we'll continue to progress as we are.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably another one of the driver that we have there is most of our historical performance whether it's in the Arcoma or down at SCOOP is on the Woodford. So we're preferentially investing in the Meramec because it's the newest of the plays, and it's, qu
componenttext: Probably another one of the driver that we have there is most of our historical performance whether it's in the Arcoma or down at SCOOP is on the Woodford. So we're preferentially investing in the Meramec because it's the newest of the plays, and it's, quite honestly, has a considerable inventory and we're continuing to progress our learnings there and therefore, focus on the early drilling.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember, the original, Gary, has a good point, the original STACK recovery was a Woodford test. That led to the recognition of the Meramec was a target, so a really good point.
componenttext: Remember, the original, Gary, has a good point, the original STACK recovery was a Woodford test. That led to the recognition of the Meramec was a target, so a really good point.

We had 5,500 locations on the books and the Anadarko Basin starting this year, and I would say the well results make us feel really bullish with regard to the upside from there.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And then on the completion improvements you've talked about [indiscernible] Can you talk about what also are you trying to do rest of the year, for instance? Is there any plans to test water completions versus the gel fracs that you're doing
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then on the completion improvements you've talked about [indiscernible] Can you talk about what also are you trying to do rest of the year, for instance? Is there any plans to test water completions versus the gel fracs that you're doing today?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's a number of things we're going to be experimenting with. Everything from gel loading to amount of proppant we use, to the type of proppant we use. We're spending a considerable amount of time looking at different diversion techniques, where w
componenttext: Yes. There's a number of things we're going to be experimenting with. Everything from gel loading to amount of proppant we use, to the type of proppant we use. We're spending a considerable amount of time looking at different diversion techniques, where we can actually go with broader stages, cut our costs but nevertheless get the same amount of stimulated rock volume. We're experimenting with the fluids. Historically, we've been pretty much using cross-linked. Today, we're actually looking at pure slick water jobs, but something that will be viewed as more of a hybrid job. And the other thing we're doing is we're looking at actually using produce waters to make up the completion fluids. So our teams are spending a considerable amount of time looking at all of those things.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
