componenttext: And our next question comes from Josh Silverstein from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you guys could just touch a little bit on some of the midstream and the processing and the take away capacity out of the basin. I know [indiscernible] guys by a little bit this quarter, so anything that you guys are working on with some of yo
componenttext: I was hoping you guys could just touch a little bit on some of the midstream and the processing and the take away capacity out of the basin. I know [indiscernible] guys by a little bit this quarter, so anything that you guys are working on with some of your providers to kind of enhance those facilities?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're -- we were limited a little bit by a turnaround on the SCOOP, that was a little bit unexpected. That since been corrected and we have full capacity down there. We don't see any limitations in the STACK. We have to have any limitations there
componenttext: Yes. So we're -- we were limited a little bit by a turnaround on the SCOOP, that was a little bit unexpected. That since been corrected and we have full capacity down there. We don't see any limitations in the STACK. We have to have any limitations there on gas it can produce. That much gas we're looking at there is kind of creative ways to go and gather the oil in lower cost. So our focus right now is on that. We don't see limitations coming around the basin. There's a number of projects that are being discussed to expand the whole corridor from STACK to SCOOP. So we're looking in participating those studies and thinking about how we're going to grow our production there. We'll also see constraints at the moment.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. Great. And then I know you talked about high-grading the -- some more of the oilier areas within the Anadarko Basin for next year's program. Is there a high-grading even within the Meramec play as of this point? And when you're thinking about the
componenttext: Got you. Great. And then I know you talked about high-grading the -- some more of the oilier areas within the Anadarko Basin for next year's program. Is there a high-grading even within the Meramec play as of this point? And when you're thinking about the Springer opportunity as you go from maybe just a handful of wells to closer to 20 or 30 wells next year, just to think about the direction there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, within the Meramec, we haven't seen any opportunities to high-grade. We're seeing pretty uniform performance like we talked about, so I think within the Meramec, as we think about SCOOP, in the Woodford, there will be a general trend for us
componenttext: First of all, within the Meramec, we haven't seen any opportunities to high-grade. We're seeing pretty uniform performance like we talked about, so I think within the Meramec, as we think about SCOOP, in the Woodford, there will be a general trend for us to move east into the more oily Woodford versus the wet gas Woodford down in SCOOP. So certainly there's going to be a move there. The plan in '16 is really not set yet. I anticipate there'll be more Springer activity than what we experienced this year but still it's more -- it's still in a state of flux there to determine exactly what those numbers would be.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And remember, the Springer, there's no real pressing need to stall HBP by our Woodford activity to have to accelerate activity. So it's simply a high-grading optionality, and we'll execute based on our plans and forward forecast.
componenttext: And remember, the Springer, there's no real pressing need to stall HBP by our Woodford activity to have to accelerate activity. So it's simply a high-grading optionality, and we'll execute based on our plans and forward forecast.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Ipsit Mohanty with GMP.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ipsit Mohanty with GMP.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just looking at your Slide 9, and I appreciate the kind of details you've given. As you go about HBP-ing the STACK, how -- what's your plan to keeping the oil really consistent? Especially, when you go into the southwest in part, you're getting into the d
componenttext: Just looking at your Slide 9, and I appreciate the kind of details you've given. As you go about HBP-ing the STACK, how -- what's your plan to keeping the oil really consistent? Especially, when you go into the southwest in part, you're getting into the dry gas window. Just curious to see whether you would go ahead and sort of actively drill that to hold it? Or would you just pass on that? Any color on that, please?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The answer is we're going to HBP our entire STACK footprint. All the wells that we're drilling within the Newfield STACK position generate attractive economics in today's commodity price well. The dry gas you referenced is Cana proper. That's historical p
componenttext: The answer is we're going to HBP our entire STACK footprint. All the wells that we're drilling within the Newfield STACK position generate attractive economics in today's commodity price well. The dry gas you referenced is Cana proper. That's historical play there in the Anadarko Basin, some big well-respected competitors in there like Devon, and Continental. They own that, it's HBP. Frankly, if we'd have the opportunity to add that acreage into the portfolio, when we're putting this position together, we've probably done it. So when you think about Newfield, I think the acreage description that we've given you in kind of the yield map, if you will, tells you the story. You go back and drill inside of the delineated wells, you're going to see average liquid yields in line with what we've delivered to day. We just don't see that there's going to be any variance going forward.

componenttext: So the working interest that we're in this kind of next year as well, is our kind of 75% of working interest range. headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: Welcome, everyone, to the Newfield Exploration Second Quarter Conference Call. For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I will turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on this very early start today. By now, I hope you've had a chance to review our release from last evening and our @NFX, which had a lot of new details on our exciting STACK play in the Anadarko Basin. We
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on this very early start today. By now, I hope you've had a chance to review our release from last evening and our @NFX, which had a lot of new details on our exciting STACK play in the Anadarko Basin. We plan to reference some of these slides in @NFX, so please have it ready during the discussion.
Speakers on our call today include Chairman, Lee Boothby; our COO, Gary Packer; and our CFO, Larry Massaro. We will all be available at the end of the prepared remarks today to answer any of your questions. [Operator Instructions]
Before handing the call over to Lee, let me remind you that today's call is being recorded, and it will be available on our website, along with today's earnings release, the accompanying financial tables and other non-GAAP reconciliations. Today's discussion will contain forward-looking estimates and assumptions that are based on our current views and our most reasonable expectations. Many factors could cause the actual results to differ materially from what we discuss this morning. A full disclaimer is provided in our earnings release and in our most recent filings with the SEC.
Thanks again for dialing in. And I'll now turn the call over to our Chairman, Lee Boothby.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. We appreciate your interest and investment in our company. Newfield is showing strong results today across the company's portfolio. You'll see in today's @NFX that we met or exceeded our expectations across all of ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone. We appreciate your interest and investment in our company. Newfield is showing strong results today across the company's portfolio. You'll see in today's @NFX that we met or exceeded our expectations across all of our operating regions. Although the focus today is on the Anadarko Basin, team Newfield [indiscernible] doing extremely well. We have markedly lowered well costs in the Anadarko and Williston Basins, and we extended the track record of exceeding production expectations in the Eagle Ford, Williston and Uinta Basins.
Our teams are looking for innovative ways to lower operating expenses and enhance margins across the business, and our efforts are flowing through our bottom line. I'm confident we have the people and assets in place today to emerge stronger and more profitable once commodity prices stabilize. But make no doubt about it, these are challenging and volatile times in the E&P business.
After about 5 years of oil prices in the 90s, we're today coming to grips with oil prices in the 50s and implications of a lower prolonged price scenario. We are proactively making strategic decisions to manage our business through today's cycle.
Our business plan differentiates Newfield today as we focused on 2 primary issues: first, ensuring that our balance sheet remained strong and that we have ample liquidity in place to build shareholder value during today's oil price environment; and to emerge stronger when prices recover. Our hedges provide certainty in our cash flows through early 2017.
Second, we are high-grading our investments. Today, nearly all of our activity is in the Anadarko Basin. There is a healthy tension between our desire to build inventory in the Anadarko Basin and accelerate STACK development and the need to protect liquidity. And today, we increased our capital budget to $1.4 billion, up $200 million. The increase relates to adding about 20,000 net acres to expand our positions in the Anadarko Basin, our decision to accelerate drilling to hold our acreage and move into full field development. Anadarko Basin is economically resilient, and our returns are improving.
By drilling an additional 15 wells in 2015, we will offset about $40 million in lease renewal expenses and ensure that 100% of our acreage is HBP by the end of next year. We believe that our business plan carefully balances these important issues.
The financial transactions we executed earlier this year strengthened our balance sheet and ensured that we have ample liquidity to not only weather a prolonged period of lower oil prices, but also to succeed and add value. We will maintain a strong balance sheet. We are focused on maintaining our leverage ratios at or near current levels, and we would look to sell other noncore assets as required to preserve our strong balance sheet and liquidity.
Exactly 1 year ago today, we were growing more concerned about the trajectory of oil prices and moved aggressively to strengthen our hedge position. Our fears were unfounded, and our hedges have been instrumental in preserving our cash flow. On mark-to-market at the end of July, our hedge position would add about $490 million in revenue in 2015 and an additional $250 million in 2016. This gives us higher certainty in our future cash flow, and we view our hedges as a differentiator amongst our peers.
Our corporate development team and the strategic planning teams have done an excellent job of mitigating risk and putting our company in a position of relative strength, and I applaud their efforts.
Over the last 5 years, we took dramatic steps to better focus our portfolio in capital investments. Before the oil price declined last year, we had executed about $2.5 billion in nonstrategic asset sales and used a large portion of the proceeds to capture and accelerate the development of SCOOP and STACK, and this has paid off. We will continue to consider using sale of additional nonstrategic assets to fund our future acceleration plans.
In early 2015, we quickly cut our capital expenditures to funneled [ph] more than 70% of our planned investments going to the Anadarko Basin. We are fortunate to have an asset today that warrants investment and provides strong returns at today's oil prices. You'll clearly see today that our returns in Anadarko Basin continues to improve.
Even with the backdrop of low oil prices, we believe it makes sense to further consolidate into one of the industry's best plays and use our competitive advantage in the Anadarko Basin. Competition for acreage in the STACK region has increased in the face of better drilling results. We are successfully adding late-stage leasehold and extensional acreage today.
With the disconnect between buyer and seller expectations for acquisition opportunities in the region, we view acreage additions as a better value proposition to exploit our distinct operating advantage. Perhaps the drop in oil prices and the realization that oil prices could stay lower for longer will create more reasonable acquisition opportunities for us in the future.
Before we go into the second quarter details, let me quickly summarize what I believe were the key takeaways in today's operations update.
Number one, our well results in STACK are improving. In today's @NFX, we share with you results from an additional 17 STACK wells and continued strong performance from our SCOOP development drilling. To date, we have drilled and completed 46 operated SXL wells in STACK. Number two, we are rapidly production-delineating our STACK acreage as we push to get it held by production. The wells we have drilled to date are geographically dispersed, and we continue to push rigs towards the edges as we align drilling plans with lease requirements. We're encouraged by the consistent and commercial results we are realizing across the acreage.
The acceleration in STACK allows us to minimize lease renewal cost through higher value drilling investments. The rigs we've added are on a well-to-well basis, and we have the ability to quickly slow investments if oil prices were to deteriorate our cash flow outlook.
Number three, our STACK wells are oil wells. We build our position in STACK in the oil window, and our wells are averaging about 80% black oil in the first 30 days of production. To date, average black oil volumes from our 46 wells are outperforming our tight curve assumptions.
Slide 11 in @NFX depicts this outperformance and supports why our confidence is continuing to grow. Later in our remarks, we'll better explain how the play transitions from wet gas to black oil across the play fairway.
Before, we're testing multiple geologic horizons, and this will be a STACK development play. To date, we have successfully tested the Upper and Lower Meramec as well as the Woodford. There are other prospective zones that we plan to test in the coming months. To date, about 70% of our STACK wells have been drilled and completed in the Meramec Shale.
We're rapidly lowering our well cost in the Anadarko Basin. This is particularly impressive in STACK, but we are not yet in full field development. Recent wells have been drilled in as few as 12 days, and our recent wells are averaging about $7.9 million including facilities. We hope to keep a good portion of these savings even in a rising oil price environment.
Our well costs today are down about $600,000 from our first quarter update. And we know that in development mode, we will easily shave another $1 million or more off the completed well cost. By now, as you simply look at what our team is building today in the Williston Basin.
And lastly, we're accelerating activity and the timing to full field development. By year-end, about 60% of our acreage in STACK will be held by production, and all of our acreage will be HBP by the end of next year. With this increased activity, we now expect that our fourth quarter production from the Anadarko Basin will average about 71,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net, and we expect to deliver strong and economic growth from SCOOP and STACK in 2016. You'll hear more on these topics when Gary provides our operational update a little later.
I'll now turn the call over to Larry Massaro to summarize our second quarter financial results. Larry?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee, and good morning, everyone. Financially, the second quarter was very solid. We're seeing the combined benefits of lower service costs, learning curve improvements and efficiency gains and our own efforts to reduce expenses and improve margins
componenttext:
Thanks, Lee, and good morning, everyone. Financially, the second quarter was very solid. We're seeing the combined benefits of lower service costs, learning curve improvements and efficiency gains and our own efforts to reduce expenses and improve margins across the business.
Year-to-date, we've invested about $730 million, excluding capitalized interest and internal costs. We expected that our investments from the second half of the year will approximate to first half, including about $400 million in the third quarter and $275 million in the fourth quarter. Our capital investment budget for the year is $1.4 billion, up $200 million. The increase is attributable to the 20,000 new acres in the Anadarko Basin, increased drilling activity and faster drilling times.
In terms of production, we extended a healthy streak of beating our projections through solid execution and strong well performance. Our domestic production in the second quarter came in at the upper end of our guidance, despite losing about 200,000 barrels equivalent related to weather and our midstream provider's curtailment in SCOOP.
Total production in the second quarter was 14.1 million barrels equivalent, of which 51% was oil and 65% was liquids. Our domestic production grew about 7% quarter-over-quarter to 12.4 million barrels equivalent. Adjusted for asset sales, this represents year-over-year growth of 13%. More importantly, our domestic liquids production was up 22% year-over-year.
The strength in our production year-to-date has allowed us to raise our full year guidance to 53.5 million to 55 million barrels equivalent, with all the increase attributed to our domestic operations. Our domestic production is now expected to be 48.5 million to 50 million barrels equivalent.
Discretionary cash flow from operations was $347 million or $2.14 per share, topping consensus estimates.
Adjusted net income for the quarter, excluding several one-time items detailed in our earnings release, was $0.46 per share. The most significant item was a noncash ceiling test write-down related to the significant drop in oil prices. As a full cost company, this charge was certainly expected and was in line with our recent disclosures in our Form 10-Q. This is a noncash charge and has no impact on our credit facility or our debt covenants. These impairments are a function of full cost accounting and significantly lower commodity price in the 12-month trailing average.
We have taken both prompt and significant steps to improve our cost structure across the company. In the second quarter, our reoccurring lease operating expenses was well below guidance at $4.60 per BOE. Second quarter LOE was lower than our full year run rate due to the timing of expected expenditures. We again lowered our full year LOE expectation to $5.20 per BOE.
As we noted last quarter, our recent restructuring and headcount reductions will reduce future G&A expense by $40 million a year, and our annual interest expense would drop by about $10 million a year due to lower interest rates associated with our debt refinancing earlier this year.
As we referenced, we are committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and ample liquidity. As we seek to leverage our competitive advantage in the Anadarko Basin and our desire to transition to full field development in STACK later next year, we know we must tailor our investment levels to the oil price environment and our cash flow expectations. 
If oil prices stay in a sub-$50 per barrel range, we would likely reduce our 2016 expenditures to maintenance mode levels. We estimate that we could maintain our domestic production levels for about $1 billion. Should prices strengthen to $55 to $60 per barrel, we are capable of strong domestic production growth, supported by improving rates of return with a capital budget similar to 2015 investment levels. Newfield clearly has high-quality options today.
At the end of the second quarter, there was nothing drawn on our revolver, and we had approximately $2 billion of liquidity. We are fortunate to be well hedged with cash flow significantly protected into 2017. 
I'll turn the call over to Gary Packer for the operations update.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. As you know, we're only allocating drilling capital to 2 areas today, the Anadarko and the Williston Basins. So let me give you an update on the Anadarko Basin and share some recent updates from our operations in STACK.In addition to STAC
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. As you know, we're only allocating drilling capital to 2 areas today, the Anadarko and the Williston Basins. So let me give you an update on the Anadarko Basin and share some recent updates from our operations in STACK.
In addition to STACK, we continue to see great results from our SCOOP and Springer plays and look forward to testing other potential geologic horizon in the basin over time.
During the second quarter, we brought online 14 new SCOOP oil wells, including our first SXL well in the Springer Shale. We continue to see good results in the development where we are running 5 rigs today.
Our overall program shifted more heavily to STACK and SCOOP oil, and the results are evident through our high oil cuts. We have 8 rigs running in STACK today. One of our most encouraging data points in today's update relates to our consistency in the STACK wells.
On Slide 7 in @NFX, we provide 30-day average production rates for 17 new wells stretched across the acreage, which covers more than 300 square miles. We now have 46 SXL wells, of which 32 have been completed in the Meramec Shale. We are confident that a significant portion of our acreage will be developed with STACK wells in both the Meramec and the Woodford. We have drilled 5 pseudo-pilots to date to test horizontal and vertical well spacing, some of which have been online for more than 1 year now. Although early, these pilots are providing encouraging results.
Please reference the geologic illustration on Slide 12 in @NFX. To date, we have successfully tested multiple wells in Upper and Lower Meramec as well as the Woodford. We have more than 700 foot of saturated interval across the large portion of our acreage, and we have taken whole course towards the acreage to better understand reservoir quality and reservoir thickness. As expected, our STACK results continue to improve, reflecting the rapid advancements we are making in our drilling and completion operations. Our most recent wells have higher 30- and 60-day rates and not all the wells have 90-day production rates yet.
On a wellhead basis, the oil percentage from these wells averaged nearly 80% over the first 30 days. We are not surprised by these high oil cuts. In fact, we intentionally captured the oil window with our initial leasing concept.
Slide 9 is important to understand. As you move from the dry gas Cana Field to the north and east across our acreage, the play transitions from a wet gas to a black oil. Note the 30-day average oil cuts across the acreage.
In addition to our first Meramec well, drilled some 4 years ago now, we also had production data for more than 3,000 vertical wells drilled over the last 50 years. These wells comingle production from a multiple zones, all sourced by the Woodford.
The GOR, or gas-oil ratios, we are seeing today are very consistent with historical production data, our predrill reservoir modeling and our tight curves. Recent well results from our North STACK acreage help validate our encouragement, and our GOR assumptions appear to be very sound.
In the first quarter, we introduced Slide 11, which originally just showed our expected oil cumes over the first decade of production. Today, we enhanced disclosure by providing you with the actual production from the 46 SXL wells we have drilled to date. You can see that the wells are highly correlative to our type curve. Furthermore, we today provided actual cumes on 21 Meramec wells with tighter frac cluster spacing. Some of these wells have now been online for nearly 1 year. Tighter frac cluster spacing is generating significantly higher oil production and has now become our norm. We continue to optimize our completion designs. You can see we are making great strides.
Based on our 950,000 barrel of oil equivalent type curve and today's lower cost, our wells are expected to pay out in just 2 years. Our returns are being enhanced by higher oil production early and the significant reductions we're making in well cost.
See slides 14 and 15 in @NFX. It's important to understand that more than half of the cost savings we have seen to date are related to efficiencies as demonstrated by reductions in days versus depth and not simply lower service costs.
Our most recent drill in complete cost in STACKwas  $7.9 million, down $600,000 from our first quarter average. We frequently participate in wells operated by others, and from this data, we know that we're clearly leading the industry in drilling days and cost. Our days to depth on our most recent operated wells have been drilled in as few as 12 days.
The real prize lies in development mode, where we are certain that we will achieve at least another $1 million savings in our completed well cost, and our teams are pushing to get us there as soon as possible.
As for other active development plays, let me close with a quick update on the Williston Basin. Our team continues to find innovative ways to improve our margins through faster drilling times, improved efficiencies and optimized completions. Recent SXL wells in the Williston Basin have been drilled in about 14 days and for an all-in cost with facilities of about $5.5 million.
Newfield has a long and proven history of driving learning curves and improving returns in full field development. The Williston is a great example. You can review recent history and see the same trends in the Eagle Ford, the Granite Wash, the Arkoma and in SCOOP. The Williston is a great proxy for where we will ultimately be heading in our STACK development.
I'll now turn the call back to Lee for closing remarks.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Gary and his teams are delivering excellent results throughout our operating regions today, and our company is well positioned to excel in today's environment.You can tell from the tone today that we are excited about our recent results in
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Gary and his teams are delivering excellent results throughout our operating regions today, and our company is well positioned to excel in today's environment.
You can tell from the tone today that we are excited about our recent results in the Anadarko Basin. It's a large scale resource play, and we have the people and the operational expertise to continue improving results and enhancing margins. We are focused on the right metrics today. We're executing across the company. We are high-grading our investments. We have effectively managed our risk. We are aggressively attacking cost and expenses and improving margins. We're exploiting our competitive advantage in the Anadarko Basin, and we are mindful of our balance sheet and we'll work to maintain a strong liquidity position.
I will close by simply saying, Newfield has high-quality options today. To date, we have delivered outstanding operating results and we intend to deliver on our full year objectives. Yes, these are challenging times, but Newfield is well positioned to continue delivering value to its stockholders today and well into the future.
Thanks for your investment in our company and we look forward to taking your questions. Operator?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: One thing, when I was looking at the forward oil guidance, I was hoping maybe you could dive into this a little bit more. Obviously, implies a trend upwards still for the balance of the year, but that's primarily domestic-oriented with international comin
componenttext: One thing, when I was looking at the forward oil guidance, I was hoping maybe you could dive into this a little bit more. Obviously, implies a trend upwards still for the balance of the year, but that's primarily domestic-oriented with international coming down. Can you just talk about the nuances to those 2 things?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as the relationship, clearly, domestically, we tightened [ph] the oil production out in the Anadarko Basin, and you're going to see a significant ramp-up as we look into the third and the fourth quarter. If you look at international, as far a
componenttext: Well, as far as the relationship, clearly, domestically, we tightened [ph] the oil production out in the Anadarko Basin, and you're going to see a significant ramp-up as we look into the third and the fourth quarter. If you look at international, as far as the cash flow that's going to be coming off of that asset, it's rather flat in 2015 and 2016 and then will decline in the future years. As far as production goes, we'll see production down in China, about 20% or 25% next year, but we're going to preserve the cash flows, just because we'll have a lack of capital spending. So everything is coming in exactly as we had anticipated, both domestically and internationally.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, just to clarify, if your question was in regards to this year, the China guidance is unchanged at 5 million barrels. The difference between the second quarter and the third quarter is simply timing of liftings. We had an extra lifting that moved int
componenttext: Dave, just to clarify, if your question was in regards to this year, the China guidance is unchanged at 5 million barrels. The difference between the second quarter and the third quarter is simply timing of liftings. We had an extra lifting that moved into the second quarter. The daily rate is around 26,000 barrels a day, so that's our peak rate from the wells that are on.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate that clarification. That's exactly what I was looking for. And then as we think about the low-price environment that we're in and the continuous loading curve that you guys are climbing rapidly in the Anadarko Basin, can you talk a litt
componenttext: Well, I appreciate that clarification. That's exactly what I was looking for. And then as we think about the low-price environment that we're in and the continuous loading curve that you guys are climbing rapidly in the Anadarko Basin, can you talk a little bit about how you balance downspacing, interval testing and completion time in this low-cost environment? Does it make more sense to find areas that holds all the production that you know you're generating strong returns and just pursuing that aggressively? Or is this more sort of balanced approach of testing all these things make more sense? Just if you could give us some clarity around that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start, Dave. If you look at @NFX, we've got dimensions on kind of the acreage footprint. You did a quick math on that. You're talking about an area that's in excess of, I mean, 1,200 square miles. If you take a look at the phase envelop date, where w
componenttext: I'll start, Dave. If you look at @NFX, we've got dimensions on kind of the acreage footprint. You did a quick math on that. You're talking about an area that's in excess of, I mean, 1,200 square miles. If you take a look at the phase envelop date, where we got all of the oil yield data, the 80% liquid yield, and we've kind of highlighted where you move from the dry gas into the wet gas, kind of say, when they're into our early acreage. Right now, with the drilling results that have been accumulated, driven by Newfield that the addition of some of the -- our friends in the industry, offset operators, if you will, you've got a box that's about 30 miles by 50 miles diagonally across that acreage position. So some 1,500 square miles that's been production delineated, and we're talking production delineated with horizontal wells. So it's a large area, and it's a large resource. Our focus, first and foremost, HBP the acreage. The acceleration program allows us to finish that process before year-end 2016. We will continue to test laterals on either side of lease lines, kind of the paired spacing that information that we've kind of put out to date just makes sense. But it doesn't make sense in our view to move away from the focus on HBP at this point to drill full spacing [indiscernible].

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's no need.
componenttext: There's no need.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: The well results have been so amazingly consistent, top to bottom, through the 700-foot thick interval that I'm kind of excited about thinking we get into development mode, we'll have a fully HBP footprint, and we'll have a couple of miles between produci
componenttext: The well results have been so amazingly consistent, top to bottom, through the 700-foot thick interval that I'm kind of excited about thinking we get into development mode, we'll have a fully HBP footprint, and we'll have a couple of miles between producing wells and we'll be able to let the team go in and develop it the right way, right upfront. So we're going to stick to our plan.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Subash Chandra with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is about those eastern wells and also, I guess, different IP 30s, how you're thinking of the economics of those wells versus those due west? And if there's any changes there in terms of cost or decline curves, I know it's early, but if t
componenttext: My first question is about those eastern wells and also, I guess, different IP 30s, how you're thinking of the economics of those wells versus those due west? And if there's any changes there in terms of cost or decline curves, I know it's early, but if there's any conclusions.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the conclusions are we're excited about those eastern tests. Recall that, that was part of the plan exiting 2014 into '15, and we're going to expand the footprint. You'll note that the overlay structurally across that acreage footprint that kind o
componenttext: I think the conclusions are we're excited about those eastern tests. Recall that, that was part of the plan exiting 2014 into '15, and we're going to expand the footprint. You'll note that the overlay structurally across that acreage footprint that kind of give you a picture that on the far eastern edge, northeastern portion of acreage footprint, TVD depths are about 8,000 feet. The western edge, you approach 12,000 feet. So clearly, there's a 4,000 foot or so change in elevation from east to west. But as far as the well results, they're very much in line with our expectations. And since the ultimate targets are shallower on the eastern side, we would expect ultimately in development mode that those wells would be cheaper than the wells drilled on the western side of the acreage. But at this point, I would say very excited and positive and results are in line with expectations.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up is, in the average wells and a couple were not included in the list as suboptimal completion. Could you just then maybe talk about how you were completing the wells and how you are now completing the wells?
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up is, in the average wells and a couple were not included in the list as suboptimal completion. Could you just then maybe talk about how you were completing the wells and how you are now completing the wells?

componenttext: Yes, I'll let Gary give you some color on that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Subash. The -- there were only 2 wells that we had excluded from the data that we provided disclosure on. Those wells both tested larger stage spacing and cluster spacing. And as a result of that, they achieved rates they're really not representative
componenttext: Yes, Subash. The -- there were only 2 wells that we had excluded from the data that we provided disclosure on. Those wells both tested larger stage spacing and cluster spacing. And as a result of that, they achieved rates they're really not representative of what we think our forward plan is. The number that we have in there, those wells produced a 60-day rate of about 625 barrels of oil equivalent a day or about 80% of the tighter spacing wells, so still very interesting wells, but we just don't think it represents what our forward plan is.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Subash, I know Gary talked about it in the call, but if we look at Slide 11, the tighter frac clusters, the Meramec are yielding higher than accelerated oil recovery, hence the focus on the tighter cluster spacing. And we've [indiscernible] proven tha
componenttext: And Subash, I know Gary talked about it in the call, but if we look at Slide 11, the tighter frac clusters, the Meramec are yielding higher than accelerated oil recovery, hence the focus on the tighter cluster spacing. And we've [indiscernible] proven that that's the way to go on as well.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Smith with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Smith with Bank of America.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we -- you guys, in the past, have done a great job of monetizing your noncore assets over the past few years. With the clear focus on the Anadarko, can you just maybe give an update on where you stand on that process and kind of where all the moving pi
componenttext: So we -- you guys, in the past, have done a great job of monetizing your noncore assets over the past few years. With the clear focus on the Anadarko, can you just maybe give an update on where you stand on that process and kind of where all the moving pieces fit in?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the steps we took earlier this year, certainly the equity raise and the revolver extension and debt offering that Gary talked about earlier leave us with $2 billion liquidity base. So I'd say first and foremost, we don't have any pressing ne
componenttext: Well, I think the steps we took earlier this year, certainly the equity raise and the revolver extension and debt offering that Gary talked about earlier leave us with $2 billion liquidity base. So I'd say first and foremost, we don't have any pressing needs to selling the assets. But I think we've been crystal clear, at least I hope we've been, I'll try to make it crystal clear in response to your question that for nonstrategic assets, it's not a question of if, it's just a question of when. And we know how hard it was to sell $2.5 billion in nonstrategic assets in the $90-world. We have no pressing need to sell it, but certainly, at the right place and time, we would sell nonstrategic assets to further accelerate activity in Anadarko. So it's not a record for that statement, but all things being equal, since we don't need to sell, I'd probably prefer to sell in something other than a $50 oil price environment.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, and I appreciate that. And also, I appreciate the commentary around 2016. I just want to make sure, first, that I understand that $55 to $60 is kind of the bogey right now for grow or don't grow. And then, I think you guys were at 10 rigs in the A
componenttext: Got it, and I appreciate that. And also, I appreciate the commentary around 2016. I just want to make sure, first, that I understand that $55 to $60 is kind of the bogey right now for grow or don't grow. And then, I think you guys were at 10 rigs in the Anadarko last quarter. Can you maybe just give an update on where you are today and what lead time you need if you do decide to ramp further.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Larry give you some color. And if he forgets anything, like he sometimes does, I'll jump in and cover him. How about that?
componenttext: I'll let Larry give you some color. And if he forgets anything, like he sometimes does, I'll jump in and cover him. How about that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, look guys, I think at $55 to $60, we're going to have nice growth rates. So I'm not worried about our ability to grow kind of differentially in the industry. When you get to $50, current oil price environment, we're still going to be in kind of more
componenttext: Yes, look guys, I think at $55 to $60, we're going to have nice growth rates. So I'm not worried about our ability to grow kind of differentially in the industry. When you get to $50, current oil price environment, we're still going to be in kind of more of a maintenance mode, but that's still probably will give us some modest growth. So don't look for us at $50 to go flat. We'll also have growth in the portfolio, the STACK and SCOOP plays are going to continue to drive that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Robert Du Boff with Oppenheimer.

componenttext: I saw you added 20,000 acres in the Anadarko Basin. Can you just talk about how costs are trending for picking up acreage and the potential to continue add there? And basically, what is your, I guess, threshold in terms of looking at maybe the gasser side of the STACK?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Robert, I appreciate your question. I think we've given all the color that I plan to give at this time. We'll keep you posted on our efforts there as the year unfolds. And at year-end, we'll give you a full update on our acreage position, where we
componenttext: Yes. So Robert, I appreciate your question. I think we've given all the color that I plan to give at this time. We'll keep you posted on our efforts there as the year unfolds. And at year-end, we'll give you a full update on our acreage position, where we're at. Let's just say that we're very pleased with the additions, and I think it makes good sense that we're able to execute on our clear competitive advantage in the basin.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And if I can get a follow-up then, just something that'll -- maybe a little more color on that $7 million level targets at the STACK. Does that just purely represent savings in full development mode, or does that contemplate any further
componenttext: Okay, understood. And if I can get a follow-up then, just something that'll -- maybe a little more color on that $7 million level targets at the STACK. Does that just purely represent savings in full development mode, or does that contemplate any further service cost cuts?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So what I said in the call was that hats off to Gary and our operating teams and our management between Gary and operating teams, [indiscernible] a fantastic job. I mean, the progress in the Williston Basin, the progress in Anadarko Basin, both SCOOP and
componenttext: So what I said in the call was that hats off to Gary and our operating teams and our management between Gary and operating teams, [indiscernible] a fantastic job. I mean, the progress in the Williston Basin, the progress in Anadarko Basin, both SCOOP and STACK, industry-leading results. Today, drilling STACK wells in as little as 12 days. You go back and look at the add-in effects and see the progression year-by-year. So these are the best kind of gains largely. They're gains from exceptional teamwork and exceptional talent, driving down the learning curve. So when we talk about experiences in the second quarter, I'll tell you that today, my expectation is $7.5-ish million are probably what I'll see for other wells, with [indiscernible] today, we're going to drive those towards $6.5 million. And hopefully, the course of moving in development, as we indicated in the call, there's another $1 million-or-so to draw that out of the equation. You can look at the Williston Basin. You can see what we've done there. Gary referenced the Arkoma. If you want to go all the way back to Granite Wash, we've done at every place which is to deploy. So these are normal, natural progressions that we expect to accrue, and we're running ahead of schedule. So at that point, I would tell you that very pleased, we've got 7 in the sights, and we're not going to stop there. Gary, do you have any color you want to add?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, there's no further service cost reductions baked into our forecast.
componenttext: I mean, there's no further service cost reductions baked into our forecast.

componenttext: And our next question comes from Leo Mariani with RBC.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could give us a little bit more detail on some of the spacing tests that you guys have in place at this point. And I guess, do you guys feel confident at this point that the Upper and Lower Meramec are distinct reservoirs? And can you may
componenttext: I was hoping you could give us a little bit more detail on some of the spacing tests that you guys have in place at this point. And I guess, do you guys feel confident at this point that the Upper and Lower Meramec are distinct reservoirs? And can you maybe talk about some of the different spacing numbers you guys are using for inter-well spacing between the Woodford, Lower and Upper Meramec?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the spacing, remember that we haven't done any full pilots at this point. So the spacing that we've got -- we're giving you all that we have. I think it's a collection of 5 different 2-well pairs that are drilled on either side of lease lines.
componenttext: In terms of the spacing, remember that we haven't done any full pilots at this point. So the spacing that we've got -- we're giving you all that we have. I think it's a collection of 5 different 2-well pairs that are drilled on either side of lease lines. If you go back and you look at these add-in effects in the last publication, all of those are diagrams. What we've done is we located outside of the lease line and we've varied spacing down to as tight as 880 feet. 880 feet would be kind of 6 wells per horizon. And we've said consistently that we're very, very encouraged with the results that we've seen. It's all we have at this point. We've tested multiple levels within the Upper Meramec, multiple levels within the Lower Meramec, and we've tested the Woodford. So we've got 3 horizons that are all working very, very nicely. And frankly, beyond that, I'll stick to the story that we've told since we announced the playback in 2013. Ultimately, we expect that there'll probably be 3 to 5 horizons exploited in the STACK play across the acreage footprint. The other side, we'll have those get it HBP and continue to accrue the data, and we'll keep you informed as those things unfold.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: I guess, just jumping over to your domestic oil production guidance in the third quarter. I'm just noticing that it's ticking down a little bit versus the second quarter numbers. So just looking for some color beyond that. It's just well timing at this point, or maybe there's some conservatism there?

componenttextpreview: Yes. Primarily what you're looking at is continued declines in those basins that we're no longer investing in, both Uinta Basin and Eagle Ford. And then it's just routine timing of pads and our developments in both SCOOP and STACK.
componenttext: Yes. Primarily what you're looking at is continued declines in those basins that we're no longer investing in, both Uinta Basin and Eagle Ford. And then it's just routine timing of pads and our developments in both SCOOP and STACK.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Dan Guffey with Stifel.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Dan Guffey with Stifel.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys have mentioned 70% of your STACK wells have targeted the Meramec. I guess, how should we think about split going forward between the Meramec and the Woodford? And then, I guess, can you discuss any performance differences between the 2 intervals?
componenttext: You guys have mentioned 70% of your STACK wells have targeted the Meramec. I guess, how should we think about split going forward between the Meramec and the Woodford? And then, I guess, can you discuss any performance differences between the 2 intervals?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that there is a slide in @NFX, I don't know if you have a chance to look at that, Dan. But you can see how we've kind of distributed the wells to date throughout the section. And 70% in the Meramec, the Meramec is the thicker of the 2 intervals wh
componenttext: I think that there is a slide in @NFX, I don't know if you have a chance to look at that, Dan. But you can see how we've kind of distributed the wells to date throughout the section. And 70% in the Meramec, the Meramec is the thicker of the 2 intervals when you think about Meramec, Woodford in terms of the pairs. So logically speaking, you could almost see 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 type distribution, just happens to be that 70% of the wells to date have been drilled in the Meramec. It was kind of our plan. So we'll continue to work through that progression. I think when we get to the end of HBP-ing the operated footprint out here, we'll probably have some few hundred plus wells that we'll be able to look at as far as the data set. And once we see the finish line for HBP, then we'll be able to start playing out kind of the full development spacing pilots and get the data that we need to really optimize that development. But at this point, we'll continue to progress as we are.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Probably another one of the driver that we have there is most of our historical performance whether it's in the Arcoma or down at SCOOP is on the Woodford. So we're preferentially investing in the Meramec, because it's the newest of the plays, and it quit
componenttext: Probably another one of the driver that we have there is most of our historical performance whether it's in the Arcoma or down at SCOOP is on the Woodford. So we're preferentially investing in the Meramec, because it's the newest of the plays, and it quite honestly, has a considerable inventory and we're continuing to progress our learnings there, and therefore, focus on the early drilling.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember, the original -- Gary makes a good point. The original STACK recovery well was a Woodford test. That led to the recognition of the Meramec was a target, so a really good point.
componenttext: Remember, the original -- Gary makes a good point. The original STACK recovery well was a Woodford test. That led to the recognition of the Meramec was a target, so a really good point.

componenttext: Okay, great. I guess, kind of ask a little bit differently, trying to look at your inventory. I guess, can you break out the percent of your total acreage that's prospective for the Woodford? And then how much do you think is prospective for both the Upper and the Lower? I know it changes as you go across the basin. But just trying to think of how many -- I know you mentioned 3 to 5 intervals, but how much of that is consistent across the entire acreage block?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's probably all the color we're going to give today. We update our inventory count annually, so you can expect the next update on inventory potential to be early next year. We had 5,500 locations on the books in the Anadarko Basin startin
componenttext: Yes, I think that's probably all the color we're going to give today. We update our inventory count annually, so you can expect the next update on inventory potential to be early next year. We had 5,500 locations on the books in the Anadarko Basin starting this year. And I would say the well results make us feel really bullish with regard to the upside from there.

componenttext: When we're talking about the STACK at this point, we're talking about the interval from the top of the Meramec to the base of Woodford and anything in between.

componenttext: We took the data that we had at year-end based on the tests and the information that's been accrued. I think if you did the simple math, you could probably come back and say that it was around 2 on average.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the completion improvements, you've talked about [indiscernible] Can you talk about what also are you planning to do rest of the year? For instance, is there any plans to test water completions versus the gel fracs that you're doing today?
componenttext: And then on the completion improvements, you've talked about [indiscernible] Can you talk about what also are you planning to do rest of the year? For instance, is there any plans to test water completions versus the gel fracs that you're doing today?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, there is a number of things we're going to be experimenting with. Everything from gel loading to amount of proppant we use, to the type of proppant we use. We're spending a considerable amount of time looking at different diversion techniques,
componenttext: Yes. Well, there is a number of things we're going to be experimenting with. Everything from gel loading to amount of proppant we use, to the type of proppant we use. We're spending a considerable amount of time looking at different diversion techniques, where we can actually go with broader stages, cut our costs, but nevertheless, get the same amount of stimulated rock volume. We're experimenting with the fluids. Historically, we've been pretty much using cross-linked. Today, we're actually looking at pure slick water jobs, but something that will be viewed as more of a hybrid job. And then the other thing we're doing is we're looking at actually using fill produced waters to make up the completion fluids. So our teams are spending a considerable amount of time looking at all of those things.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Josh Silverstein from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Josh Silverstein from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you guys could just touch a little bit on the -- on some of the midstream and the processing and the takeaway capacity out of the basin. I know [indiscernible] guys by a little bit this quarter. So anything that you guys are working on with s
componenttext: I was hoping you guys could just touch a little bit on the -- on some of the midstream and the processing and the takeaway capacity out of the basin. I know [indiscernible] guys by a little bit this quarter. So anything that you guys are working on with some of your providers to kind of enhance those facilities?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're -- we were limited a little bit by a turnaround on the SCOOP. That was a little unexpected. That has since been corrected, and we have full capacity down there. We don't see any limitations in the STACK. We don't have any limitations there o
componenttext: Yes. So we're -- we were limited a little bit by a turnaround on the SCOOP. That was a little unexpected. That has since been corrected, and we have full capacity down there. We don't see any limitations in the STACK. We don't have any limitations there on gas that it can produce. That much gas we're looking at there is kind of [indiscernible] ways to go, gather the oil and lower cost. So our focus right now is on that. We don't see limitations going around the basin. There's a number of projects that are being discussed to expand the whole corridor from STACK to SCOOP. So we're looking in and participating in those studies and thinking about how we're going to grow our production there. We don't see constraints at the moment.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you, great. And then I know you talked about high-grading the -- more of the oilier areas within the Anadarko Basin for next year's program. Is there a high-grading even within the Meramec play as of this point? And when you're thinking about the Spri
componenttext: Got you, great. And then I know you talked about high-grading the -- more of the oilier areas within the Anadarko Basin for next year's program. Is there a high-grading even within the Meramec play as of this point? And when you're thinking about the Springer opportunity, is it going from maybe just a handful of wells to closer to 20 or 30 wells next year, just to think about the direction there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, within the Meramec, we haven't seen any opportunities to high-grade. We're seeing pretty uniform performance, like we talked about. So nothing within the Meramec. As we think about SCOOP, in the Woodford, there will be a general trend for us
componenttext: First of all, within the Meramec, we haven't seen any opportunities to high-grade. We're seeing pretty uniform performance, like we talked about. So nothing within the Meramec. As we think about SCOOP, in the Woodford, there will be a general trend for us to move east into the more oily Woodford versus the wet gas Woodford down in SCOOP. So certainly there's going to be a move there. The plan in '16 is really not set yet. I anticipate there'll be more Springer activity than what we experienced this year. But still, it's more -- it's still in a state of flux there to determine exactly what those numbers would be.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, remember, the Springer, there's no real pressing need to install HBP by our Woodford activity to have the accelerated activity. So it's simply a high-grading optionality, and we'll execute based on our plans and forward forecast.
componenttext: Yes, remember, the Springer, there's no real pressing need to install HBP by our Woodford activity to have the accelerated activity. So it's simply a high-grading optionality, and we'll execute based on our plans and forward forecast.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Ipsit Mohanty with GMP.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Ipsit Mohanty with GMP.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just looking at your Slide 9, and I appreciate the kind of details you've given, but as you go about HBP-ing the STACK, how -- what's your plan to keeping the oil really consistent, especially when you go into the southwestern part, you're getting into th
componenttext: Just looking at your Slide 9, and I appreciate the kind of details you've given, but as you go about HBP-ing the STACK, how -- what's your plan to keeping the oil really consistent, especially when you go into the southwestern part, you're getting into the dry gas window? Just curious to see whether you would go ahead and sort of actively drill that to hold it? Or would you just pass on that? Any color on that, please?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the answer is we're going to HBP our entire STACK footprint. All the wells that we're drilling within the Newfield STACK position generate attractive economics in today's commodity price oil. The dry gas that you referenced is Cana proper. That's histo
componenttext: So the answer is we're going to HBP our entire STACK footprint. All the wells that we're drilling within the Newfield STACK position generate attractive economics in today's commodity price oil. The dry gas that you referenced is Cana proper. That's historical play there in the Anadarko Basin, some big, well respected competitors in there like Devon, Zimmerex [ph] and Continental. They own that. It's HBP. Frankly, if we'd have the opportunity to add that acreage into the portfolio, when we're putting this position together, we'd have probably done it. So when you think about Newfield, I think the acreage description that we've given you in kind of the yield map, if you will, tells you the story. You go back and drill inside of the delineated wells, you're going to see average liquid yields in line with what we've delivered to date. We just don't see it if there's going to be any variance going forward.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And if I heard you correctly, you're running 8 rigs in the STACK now. Could you please give us the number of rigs you ran in the SCOOP and STACK in 2Q and currently?

componenttext: In 2Q, we would have had 5 rigs running in SCOOP and 5 rigs running in STACK.

componenttext: And right now?
