componenttext: Yes. Sew let me -- outside of the kind of high level commentary. I don't know that we said that we weren't doing anymore pilot tests between now, and year end indicating that we will have ongoing well pairs, 2 well pairs. We have no specific multi-wilson facing what it's been put, but we do continue -- we do plan to continue to build to well peers where we can across the acreage the fits, to some extent, doing a guided that information. I think, the results of that we've seen from all of the rest of the released to date have been in line or above the published type curves, so we've been very pleased there. We've not seen any negative interference effects or degradation. So another thing to be very pleased with. The closest we've been able to get, 880 feet, I believe in the reason for that is when you drill across the slide, state couple more books, that's as close that we can get. So practically speaking, that's about this was per horizon if you want to think about it at that level. I think, we've feel pretty comfortable with the results we're seeing there. We'll have to wait for the mood to shift in the development to drill multi-well pilots, and I'm sure we'll test spacing tighter than that once again there, but right now, we're very encouraged with the results. We'll continue to add the data set. When we get the acreage footprint, HBP, that's going to be a pretty fantastic place to be, so we have all of that spacing and well performance data before we ever actually get into the development mode that's a luxury we haven't had in any of the previous plays.

componenttext: So I would tell you that we'll continue to learn as we move through the development of this play. I would expect to see continued improvements, as we said, earlier. I think, the key to remember is our team starts at time 0 in these plays not to chase press releases and big IPs, but to design the development well. So we're working on that development well designs today. We want compact, type, complex fraction networks, and that's really what the focus is. I would take you back, if we talked, and I'm sure you've heard Steve and others and some of the materials that we put out, I love looking at what the team's accomplished in the Williston Basin. And we're drilling and completing 21,000, 22,000 foot wells there today for $5 million, including facilities. And those wells are virtually identical to the types of wells that we'll be drilling in STACK. So we get the development vote. I wouldn't bet against.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome everyone to the Newfield Exploration Third Quarter Conference Call. For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I'll turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please begin.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome everyone to the Newfield Exploration Third Quarter Conference Call. For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I'll turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please begin.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. By now, we hope you've had a good chance to review our release and the @NFX that we issued last night. The slides and @NFX will be helpful references during our call today. Following prepared remarks from our
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. By now, we hope you've had a good chance to review our release and the @NFX that we issued last night. The slides and @NFX will be helpful references during our call today. Following prepared remarks from our Chairman, Lee Boothby, we will have our executive team assembled and ready to take your questions. [Operator Instructions] Let me remind you that today's call is being recorded and will be available on our website along with our earnings release, the accompanying financial tables and non-GAAP reconciliations.
Today's discussion contains forward-looking estimates and assumptions based on our current views and most reasonable expectations. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discuss today. A full disclaimer is provided in our earnings release and in our most recent 10-K and 10-Q.
Thank you, again, for dialing in today, and I'll turn it over to our Chairman, Lee Boothby.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone and thanks for dialing in for our Third Quarter Conference Call. Your investment in our company is very much appreciated and we look forward to providing you with a solid operational update today as well as taking you
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone and thanks for dialing in for our Third Quarter Conference Call. Your investment in our company is very much appreciated and we look forward to providing you with a solid operational update today as well as taking your questions at the end of our prepared remarks. 
It's hard to believe that 2015 is drawing to a close. Despite the challenges presented by low commodity prices, Newfield has worked to differentiate itself from the pack through solid execution, quality assets and a sound business plan. We're executing very well across the organization today. Although the lion's share of the capital is being invested in the Anadarko Basin, we continue to deliver best-in-class wells in the Williston Basin, and we're actively working to improve our base production levels and reduce our cost structure across the enterprise. We truly have an all hands on deck mentality today and we're aligned to deliver on our key goals. Just as important as today's production beat is the progress we've made to lower our cost and expenses. Notice that our third quarter cash operating expenses were significantly lower than guidance. We're building on these efficiencies as we prepare to enter 2016 and leaving no stone unturned when it comes to the pursuit of margin expansion. We're successfully retooling our company to be profitable in a lower commodity price world. Newfield's differentiated in several distinct ways today. First, we are focused. Over that last 5 years, we've sold nonstrategic assets, reinvested proceeds into our plays of the future. We have aligned -- realigned our organizational structure to reduce G&A expenses while deploying talent to our highest return plays, SCOOP and STACK. Second, we have demonstrated the ability to effectively manage the inherent risk in the E&P business. We took proactive steps last year to ensure our cash flow by hedging a significant portion of our production into 2017. In addition, we strengthened our balance sheet and liquidity position through key capital market transactions earlier this year. Our strong financial footing has been paramount to building shareholder value in today's oil price environment. We intend to emerge as a better, stronger and more profitable company when commodity prices recover. And lastly, we are very fortunate to have an asset that can deliver both strong returns and growth in a low oil price environment. The Anadarko Basin offers strong returns today, and we know that development economics will be significantly better tomorrow. We are highly encouraged with the results we're seeing today in the Anadarko Basin. There is a comprehensive update in today's @NFX publication. You will see that our teams continue to advance learnings to deliver superior well results, optimize completions and improve returns. It's important to note the for the first time, our net daily production from the Anadarko Basin has now eclipsed the combined production from the remainder of our domestic assets. This is quite a milestone considering that the SCOOP and STACK plays literally started from scratch just 4 years ago. Due to the strong growth in the Anadarko Basin and our efforts to maximize base production across the company, we, today, raised our full year expectations for 2015 production, and we will enter 2016 with strong operational momentum. In STACK, we have now drilled nearly 70 wells and have seen strong well results across our acreage. With each well, we again increased confidence in the play, although the primary focus of our STACK drilling program is the HBP our acreage, we are learning about well spacing, both on the surface and sub-surface, and we will be ready to enter full field development in 2017. Our growing Anadarko Basin assets provide us with a deep inventory of high return drilling locations that will lead Newfield's growth and profitability for many years to come. Other critical 2015 initiatives relate to our efforts to improve margins across the company. We have worked to significantly improve our cost structure. These gains have many contributors, including high-graded capital investments; reduced service cost; innovative efforts to lower LOE; redeployment of our people; and the rightsizing of our workforce. Our estimated 2015 lease operating expenses on a unit of production basis are expected to be nearly 25% below 2014 levels. We're expecting that LOE will be down an additional 5% to 10% from current levels in 2016. Our 2015 estimated net G&A expense will be down about $25 million over 2014 levels, adjusted for onetime reorganization costs. Our 2016 G&A expense is expected to be down $40 million from this year's level.
In addition, our future realized prices are expected to improve in STACK through better oil price differentials. We're seeing great demand for our STACK barrels today due to both API gravity, crude quality and geographic location.
Before covering our financial results for the third quarter, let me make a few preliminary comments about 2016 and how we are seeing our business plan taking shape. We're running multiple scenarios in preparation for 2016. Although fluid, I can share with you some of the bookends around our analysis. First, we're working toward a capital budget that substantially balances with our expectations for cash flow, inclusive of hedge revenues. As we've said repeatedly, our primary focus today is on maintaining liquidity and a strong balance sheet. We expect to enter 2016 with ample capacity under our $1.8 billion credit facility. This is an investment-grade facility with no redetermination concerns. It's term was extended earlier this year out to 2020. We estimate that our maintenance capital funding level is around $900 million, nearly $800 million would be associated with drilling and completions and the remainder will be allocated to infrastructure, leasehold and land renewals. At today's strip prices, our 2016 hedges should add about $260 million in revenues.
This year, Anadarko Basin volumes will be up nearly 50% over 2014 levels. We enter 2016 with momentum and expect that the continuing growth of SCOOP and STACK in 2016 will more than offset the natural declines in our other domestic areas that are not receiving capital investments today. Our production throughout 2016 is expected to be relatively flat throughout the course of the year should we undertake maintenance capital investment levels. This will put us in a great position to accelerate, and again, focus on strong growth once the commodity prices provide the appropriate catalyst. We plan to issue our final 2016 capital budget and guidance along with our fourth quarter and year-end earnings in February of 2016. We are confident in our plan's ability to maintain a strong balance sheet, generate lower operating cost, improve our returns and advance STACK toward full field development in 2017.
Let me quickly recover our financial results for the third quarter. Increasing volumes, coupled with improved costs in the unit production basis define the quarter's highlights. Margin improvements were evident in our cash operating cost. On a unit of production basis, LOE was 15% below our guidance for the quarter and nearly 25% below the comparable period in 2014. G&A expense, excluding onetime costs associated with our reduction in force, and restructuring cost was about $3 million less than guidance. Our capital investment budget for the year remains approximately $1.4 billion and includes capital invested year-to-date to acquire additional land and leasehold in the Anadarko Basin. For the first 9 months of this year, we sold $77 million of nonstrategic assets as we continue to refine our portfolio and high-grade investments. Year-to-date we've invested about $1.1 billion, excluding capitalized interest and internal cost. There's a helpful table on Page 4 in @NFX that outlets capital investments by quarter, which includes our change in accruals. In terms of production, we extended a healthy streak of beating our projections through solid execution and improving well performance. Our domestic production in the third quarter exceeded our guidance midpoint by 400,000 barrels led by the Anadarko Basin. For the third quarter, our production in the Anadarko Basin came in about 2,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day ahead of our forecast, split equally among our 3 primary commodity products. Total production in the third quarter was 14.3 million of oil equivalent, of which is 63% was liquids. Our consolidated oral production during the quarter was 42% higher than the same period as 2014, adjusted for asset sales.
Domestic production was up 10% year-over-year, adjusted for asset sales. Domestic production grew 3% quarter-over-quarter to 12.9 million barrels of oil equivalent. We lifted about 1.4 million barrels of China during the quarter, surpassing our guidance by the about 125,000 barrels. Due to our production outperformance year-to-date, we are, again, raising our annual forecast. Our full year company guidance is now 55.3 million to 55.8 million barrels of oil equivalent. Our domestic production is now expected to be 50.0 million to 50.5 million barrels of oil equivalent. Discretionary cash flow from operations was $280 million or $1.72 per share. Discretionary cash flows were a couple of pennies light to consensus, primarily due to divesting or payout of previously expensed cash settled restricted stock in the third quarter as well as severance and other reorganization costs. Adjusted net income for the quarter, which excludes several onetime items detailed in our release was $0.21 per share. The most significant item was a noncash ceiling test right now related to the significant drop in oil prices. As a full cost company, this charge was certainly expected and was in line with our recent disclosures in our Form 10-Q. This is a noncash charge and has no impact on our credit facility or debt covenants. These impairments are a function of full cost accounting and significantly lower commodity prices in a 12-month trailing average. Let's move onto our operations update. I'll spend the rest of today on the Anadarko Basin. We're excited about our recent results, which demonstrate material gains in several important areas. First, improving well performance. You can see from today's results that our production from the Anadarko Basin is tracking well above expectations. Today, we raised expectations for our fourth quarter average daily rate from the Anadarko Basin to about 74,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day ahead of our beginning of year estimate and 3,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, higher than our estimate last quarter. Second, we're seeing continued gains in drilling efficiencies, which are leading towards lower well cost. In our STACK play, our estimate of well cost at the beginning of the year was $8.5 million. Today, we're drilling and completing wells for $7.5 million or less. Our days to depth are averaging about 16 days and our best-in-class wells start are drilled in 12 days. Third, we're effectively optimizing completions. We're making material advancements in our completions and early results are very promising. And lastly, we're planning for future development. We have a marketing agreements now in plays for both oil and gas takeaway in STACK, and we are developing an extensive network to allow for the distribution, recycling and reuse of our frac flowback water. This will be advantageous as we enter full field development. 
Let's talk about each of these gains starting with the improved well performance. In @NFX, we released results from 22 new SXL wells. We now have 68 wells in our STACK data set and the results have been very consistent across an area that covers more than 1,500 square miles and spans more than 50 miles from corner to corner. In fact, there's a tighter correlation in our STACK results than any of the resource plays we've been associated with today. Our most recent well's in higher 30- and 60-day rates and not all of the wells have yet reached 90-day production rates. Average a 30-day rates from our 22 new wells exceeded last quarter's wells by 100 barrels of oil equivalent per day. On a wellhead basis, the oil percentage from our new wells average nearly 80% over the first 30 days of production.By the end of this year, we expect to have drilled about 100 STACK wells. This is a very significant data set and is providing us with high confidence in our future forecast. SCOOP is in full development and pad drilling is generating strong returns. Our recent Williams 5-well pad came on at about 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day gross of which 70% was oil on a 2-stream basis. We had 2 additional SCOOP pads that will begin production shortly and help push our average net production from the Anadarko Basin to about 74,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the fourth quarter. We continue to lower well cost in STACK through innovative bit designs, mud and motor optimizations and the targeting of the most effective drilling zones within the Meramec and Woodford. Today, well cost are about $7.5 million, but more importantly, we can see the path to significantly lower well cost once we move to pad drilling in full field development. We estimate that more than half of the cost savings seen to-date is related to efficiencies and fuel optimizations and not simply a result of lower service cost. From our participation in outside operator wells, we know we are leading industry in drilling days and cost. Perhaps, our most significant developments today are coming through recent completion optimizations. Recall that our first 26 STACK wells had identical completions. We felt early that it was critical to have a large consistent sample set across our acreage footprint. In 2015, we began to optimize completions in both SCOOP and STACK, adjusting different variables to fund the optimal well for full field development. Recent variables explore the use of zipper fracs, diverting agents, high concentrations of fluids and proppants and slip water fracs. We're very encouraged by the early performance results from these optimizations. Within a larger sample set in time, we will know the magnitude of the impact on our EURs and rates of return. Stay tuned, we'll have more to share with you in the way of data very soon. 
We recently signed new agreements that will help ensure that we have good markets in the possible differentials for our growing STACK production. As today, our STACK oil is trucked to Cushing, Oklahoma. Under our new agreements, we will begin piping about 1/3 of our STACK production in January of 2016 and by the end of the second quarter, 100% of our STACK oil be piped into Cushing. We've seen a growing appetite for our STACK barrel, which is a 42 to 45-degree API barrel. We will soon have the ability to batch oil to ensure the best price. We expect our differential to NYMEX WTI will decrease from about $4.50 per barrel today to about $2.50 per barrel early next year. As you can tell, our remarks today, we are very encouraged with the continuing progress that we're making in the Anadarko Basin. And we'll be happy to discussed additional details during our Q&A. 
So in closing, I'd like to say Newfield is in a very good plays today. We didn't arrive here by chance. We took the right steps 12 to 18 months ago and hedged forward all sales to ensure our cash flow. We upsized and extended our credit facility through 2020, ensuring our liquidity position and eliminating redetermination risk, and we sold $2.5 billion in assets at yesterday's commodity prices. These strategic decisions were timely and help with Newfield in an advantage position today despite a vary challenging microenvironment. We are fortunate that we can provide our shareholders with both volumes and value. Growth in shareholder value creation are not mutually exclusive regardless of where we find ourselves in the inevitable commodity price cycles. Thanks for your investment in our company, and we look forward to taking your questions. Operator?

componenttext: So we saw a nice uptick in the STACK well productivity. When you take a look at the latest SCOOP oil wells with the 90-day oil production, looks like there was a bit of a drop in the percentage oil, my calculation's like 42% versus 51% from the earlier results, I might be off a little bit. But what was the main driver for those declines?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's important when you look at the Anadarko Basin and SCOOP and STACK, and I'll get to that specific question in a moment, so remember that we're drilling across various positions within phase envelopes. So you're going to see a natural vari
componenttext: Yes. I think it's important when you look at the Anadarko Basin and SCOOP and STACK, and I'll get to that specific question in a moment, so remember that we're drilling across various positions within phase envelopes. So you're going to see a natural variation across the play. We've got plenty of data. We know where we are in the phase envelopes, so we know what the expectations are, but from quarter-to-quarter or data set to data set, you'll have pad wells coming into play. And as we move towards the development, you'll have both the noise that comes in from OBO activity as well, but small variations, a few percentage points, one way or the other, are nothing could be concerned about. So what I would tell you, in the SCOOP wells, and we have the 5-well pad that was referenced, we're very, very pleased with the results and they're in line with our expectations in the play. And the same is true with regard to STACK. I can't think of the last time we had any surprises with regard to face composition and production types in this play. We got plenty of data, and it's pretty well-defined at this stage.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, like I said carefully, that we're going to come up with our final guidance which will include an update on the portfolio, well count locations and 2016 mix in February '16. We're going to stick to that schedule. The commentary on maintenance capital
componenttext: Well, like I said carefully, that we're going to come up with our final guidance which will include an update on the portfolio, well count locations and 2016 mix in February '16. We're going to stick to that schedule. The commentary on maintenance capital is to give you a reference point that we've said pretty consistently on the road since earlier this year that in a $50 and below world that you can probably expect Newfield to execute a balanced plan. We're presently in a 50-ish dollar world. When you think about it in this regard, so we're thinking that's more likely or not, we'll have a balanced program going into 2016. Put ourselves in a position to time the recovery, if you will, and the commodity and step on the accelerator at the right time but balanced program is the right place to go, and it will be Anadarko-centric. We'll have to finish our HBP drilling, which should be a large part of our activity in 2016. And then once we move into the full field development stage in STACK, initially 2017 forward, you'll have a more consistent forecast from that point forward.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttextpreview: Well, we've been careful to say that -- and I think we've demonstrated with $2.5 billion of asset sales that funded our transformation, every asset has a life cycle. So over the course of time, it's not a question of if, it's when. And clearly, we do have
componenttext: Well, we've been careful to say that -- and I think we've demonstrated with $2.5 billion of asset sales that funded our transformation, every asset has a life cycle. So over the course of time, it's not a question of if, it's when. And clearly, we do have other assets in the portfolio we could consider for divestment investment, but specific answer to you question, we have nothing, no planed sales at this point in time. We do have assets that would be considered for this position at the right place and time when we choose to accelerate activity in Anadarko Basin. So the answer to that is yes, not today.

componenttext: Leo, I think the other thing to remember when you at overall data set as we approach 70 odd wells through the course of the drilling, we've got about 2/3 of the total test in the Meramec and about 1/3 in the Woodford, if I remember. Obviously, as we move around HBP and there will be places where we test the Meramec in places where we're testing Woodford, but it's been roughly pretty consistent around 2/3, 1/3 over that time period, last 4 years.

componenttext: All right, that's helpful. I just wanted to qualify the one comment that you made, Lee. You talked about that theoretical maintenance CapEx of $900 million in flattish production. Is that flat year-over-year in '16 versus full year '15? Or was that flat with fourth quarter of '15?

componenttext: Just looking at the significant improvement you're showing quarter-over-quarter on STACK wells, to the extent that you can, what's the biggest reason for these wells? Is it just drilling completion techniques? Or is it something in the acreage that you're going and drilling at various portions?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that I've listed a whole smattering of things that we're testing, and I guess the first thing I would tell you is remember that we're relatively early in this data set. Not all of the wells have made it to 90 days, so we have got 30- and
componenttext: Well, I would say that I've listed a whole smattering of things that we're testing, and I guess the first thing I would tell you is remember that we're relatively early in this data set. Not all of the wells have made it to 90 days, so we have got 30- and 60-day data. The focus is on optimizing completions and we've kind of got a menu, it's sort of an all of the above things that makes sense. I listed diverters. We've previously talked about reductions in cluster spacing on the perfs. Targeting, where do you target within the various horizons for the best completions. It's a combination of a lot of factors, but I think the follow-on point that you're probably wanting to ask is, when do you see this translate through the EUR. We'll give you our updates on our thoughts on the EUR when we come up with our 2016 plan but, clearly, 100 barrel oil equivalent per day increase in the average, quarter-over-quarter, 1,000 barrels a day-type, 30-day IPs, we're excited about it. I think that's a key take away.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then when you talk about -- when you talk about maintenance capital, there's not a goal, I believe, of achieving HBP in the STACK. Is that possible by year-end '16 with the maintenance capital? Or do you need to push it to '17?
componenttext: Great. And then when you talk about -- when you talk about maintenance capital, there's not a goal, I believe, of achieving HBP in the STACK. Is that possible by year-end '16 with the maintenance capital? Or do you need to push it to '17?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that, again, what we said earlier this year is that we were's going to stay aggressively focused on HBP-ing our STACK acreage as that was kind of our pressing need. Now we're fortunate that we have high return wells that we're drilling, we'r
componenttext: Well, I think that, again, what we said earlier this year is that we were's going to stay aggressively focused on HBP-ing our STACK acreage as that was kind of our pressing need. Now we're fortunate that we have high return wells that we're drilling, we're not in development mode so typically, we'll drill a 10,000-foot well, and we'll protect 2 sections and then we'll move about 2 miles away and we'll drill the next 2 sections. So it's a lot of work. We'll be at about 100 wells at the end of this year. We'll need to touch over 200 wells to get the core footprint HBP. So it tells you that there'll be a lot of drilling, the rig count is shifting in favor of STACK. That's been happening during the course of the year. I would guess that at a level of funding that you talked about, $900 million, $1 billion type funding, somewhere in that zip code, we'll be 90%-plus HBP by the end of the year and we'll finish up the HBP early in 2017.

componenttext: The stock wells continue to show improvements in productivity whether you measure it in absolute terms or on a per foot of lateral basis. What should we expect in terms of the rate of change going forward, given the completion optimization, operations under way today?

componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the shortest answer is that it's still early innings. I think, there's a lot going on, a lot that we're doing, a lot that other competitors in the play are doing. I think we're all learning from each other. Clearly, I would expect to se
componenttext: Well, I think that the shortest answer is that it's still early innings. I think, there's a lot going on, a lot that we're doing, a lot that other competitors in the play are doing. I think we're all learning from each other. Clearly, I would expect to see some continued learning and positive results related thereto. But the pace, the actual rate of that change, I'm not going to try to answer that today, I just think that we're still early innings and there'll be some more wins before this is over with.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to dive in a little bit more on spacing. I know you mentioned you're done with spacing tests for this year. Just curious, your thoughts on -- if 880 feet or 6 wells per section is the right spacing. And then also, on your third and fourth test
componenttext: Just wanted to dive in a little bit more on spacing. I know you mentioned you're done with spacing tests for this year. Just curious, your thoughts on -- if 880 feet or 6 wells per section is the right spacing. And then also, on your third and fourth test that you guys did, I guess, your third specifically as you are previously defining it, you had 2 in the Meramec that were stacked and staggered, vertical spacing was around 175 feet, are you seeing any degradation or communication that's pushing down or pulling down some of those production rates from those pilots? Or are all of them, essentially, at/or above your type curves?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me -- I'll start with a kind of high level commentary. I don't know that we said that we weren't doing anymore pilot tests between now and year end. I think that we'll have ongoing well pairs, 2 well pairs. We have no specific multi-wells faci
componenttext: Yes. So let me -- I'll start with a kind of high level commentary. I don't know that we said that we weren't doing anymore pilot tests between now and year end. I think that we'll have ongoing well pairs, 2 well pairs. We have no specific multi-wells facing -- pilots being drilled. But we do continue -- we do plan to continue to drill 2 well pairs where we can across the acreage footprint, just to make sense, so you can gather the information. I think the results that we've seen from all of the wells that we've released to-date have been in line or above the published type curves, so we've been very pleased there. We've not seen any negative interference effects or degradation. So another thing to be very pleased with. The closest we've been able to get, 880 feet, I believe, and the reason for that is when you drill across lease lines, State of Oklahoma rules, that's as close as we can get. So practically speaking, that's about 6 wells per horizon, if you wanted to think about it at that level. I think we feel pretty comfortable with the results we're seeing there. We'll have to wait for the mood to shift into development to drill multi-well pilots, and I'm sure we'll test spacing tighter than that once we get there. But right now, we're very encouraged with the results. We'll continue to add to the data set. When we get the acreage footprint, HBP, that's going to be a pretty fantastic place to be. Because we will have all of that spacing and well performance data before we ever actually get into the development mode, that's a luxury we haven't had in any of the previous plays.

componenttext: Okay, great. So it sounds like the data, what you gathered this year, the inventory number that you provided at the beginning of the year, this year, should -- the inventory in STACK should significantly increase when you put your numbers out in February of '16. Is that correct?

componenttext: Well, I think we're very encouraged. We'll update the inventory and the well counts and give you that information as part of our year-end data set, consistent with what we've been doing the last 2 or 3 years.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then again, on optimizations. I know you said you're kind of -- it's a full menu of trying out many different types. I guess, how close do you guys feel like you are to reaching optimization? And do you think all of '16 will get you to wh
componenttext: Okay, great. And then again, on optimizations. I know you said you're kind of -- it's a full menu of trying out many different types. I guess, how close do you guys feel like you are to reaching optimization? And do you think all of '16 will get you to where you need to be when you're in your full field development mode and actually have a recipe that you consistently used?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would tell you that we'll continue to learn as we move through the development of this play. I would expect to see continued improvements, as we said earlier. I think the key to remember is our team starts at time 0 in these plays, not to chase press
componenttext: So I would tell you that we'll continue to learn as we move through the development of this play. I would expect to see continued improvements, as we said earlier. I think the key to remember is our team starts at time 0 in these plays, not to chase press releases and big IPs, but to design the development well. So we're working on the development well designs today. We want compact, tight, complex fraction networks, and that's really what the focus is. I would take you back, I don't know if we've talked, Dan, but I'm sure you've heard Steve and others and some of the materials we've put out. I love looking at what the team's accomplished in the Williston Basin. And we're drilling and completing 21,000, 22,000-foot wells there today for $5 million, including facilities. And those wells are virtually identical to the types of wells that we'll be drilling in STACK. So we get to development mode, I wouldn't bet against Newfield.

Or is that just -- or do you still get to the same mix of kind of 400,000 barrels of oil and 950,000 barrels equivalent from an EUR standpoint? Just trying to get an idea of -- oil's making it but does gas and NGL even be more and give you some more juice?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think that the politest answer I can give today is let us accumulate some more time on the wells that we've released today. We're going to add additional wells in the course of the fourth quarter. So it will go into next year with 100 wells i
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think that the politest answer I can give today is let us accumulate some more time on the wells that we've released today. We're going to add additional wells in the course of the fourth quarter. So it will go into next year with 100 wells in our data set. So the data set's growing at a pretty rapid pace in that regard. Clearly, what the uplift that you're seeing early on the early returns on these wells, my expectation is that it will ultimately translate to an uptick in EUR so you'll see improvement across the product mix: oil, NGLs and gas.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll stick to the same comment. We'll give you the '16 absolute figures when we come out in February with that data. The trend line, I think you're onto a good line of reasoning, I think the Anadarko is going to become a more dominant part of the
componenttext:
Yes. So I'll stick to the same comment. We'll give you the '16 absolute figures when we come out in February with that data. The trend line, I think you're onto a good line of reasoning, I think the Anadarko is going to become a more dominant part of the portfolio. We mentioned in the call that we've gone past 50% and clearly, the margins are improving there. So the Anadarko Basin, the economic draw, the gravitational pull we've been talking about the last 2 or 3 years just continues to get stronger and stronger. It will translate to materially improved margins, 2016 forward. 
Well, I guess -- I think that was the last call. So we'll go ahead and thank everybody for tuning in this morning. I appreciate the questions. We look forward to updating you on full year 2015 results and our 2016 plan going forward. And again, thanks for your interest and investment in Newfield. Have a good day.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome, everyone, to the Newfield Exploration Third Quarter Conference Call. For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I'll turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please begin.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome, everyone, to the Newfield Exploration Third Quarter Conference Call. For opening remarks and other housekeeping items, I'll turn the call over to Steve Campbell, Head of Investor Relations. Please begin.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. By now, we hope you've had a good chance to review our release and the @NFX that we issued last night. The slides and @NFX will be helpful references during our call today. Following prepared remarks from our
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. By now, we hope you've had a good chance to review our release and the @NFX that we issued last night. The slides and @NFX will be helpful references during our call today. Following prepared remarks from our Chairman, Lee Boothby, we will have our executive team assembled and ready to take your questions. [Operator Instructions] Let me remind you that today's call is being recorded and will be available on our website along with our earnings release, the accompanying financial tables and non-GAAP reconciliations.
Today's discussion contains forward-looking estimates and assumptions based on our current views and most reasonable expectations. Many factors could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discuss today. A full disclaimer is provided in our earnings release and in our most recent 10-K and 10-Q.
Thanks again, for dialing in today, and I'll turn it over to our Chairman, Lee Boothby.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone and thanks for dialing in to our Third Quarter Conference Call. Your investment in our company is very much appreciated and we look forward to providing you with a solid operational update today, as well as taking you
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good morning, everyone and thanks for dialing in to our Third Quarter Conference Call. Your investment in our company is very much appreciated and we look forward to providing you with a solid operational update today, as well as taking your questions at the end of our prepared remarks. 
It's hard to believe that 2015 is drawing to a close. Despite the challenges presented by low commodity prices, Newfield has worked to differentiate itself from the pack through solid execution, quality assets and a sound business plan. We're executing very well across the organization today. Although the lion's share of capital is being invested in the Anadarko Basin, we continue to deliver best-in-class wells in the Williston Basin, and we're actively working to improve our base production levels and reduce our cost structure across the enterprise. We truly have an all-hands-on-deck mentality today and we're aligned to deliver on our key goals. Just as important as today's production beat is the progress we've made to lower our cost and expenses. Notice that our third quarter cash operating expenses were significantly lower than guidance. We're building on these efficiencies as we prepare to enter 2016 and leaving no stone unturned when it comes to the pursuit of margin expansion. We're successfully retooling our company to be profitable in a lower commodity price world. Newfield's differentiated in several distinct ways today. First, we are focused. Over the last 5 years, we have sold nonstrategic assets, reinvested proceeds into our plays of the future. We have aligned -- realigned our organizational structure to reduce G&A expenses while deploying talent to our highest-return plays, SCOOP and STACK. Second, we have demonstrated the ability to effectively manage the inherent risk in the E&P business. We took proactive steps last year to ensure our cash flow by hedging a significant portion of our production into 2017. In addition, we strengthened our balance sheet and liquidity position through key capital market transactions earlier this year. Our strong financial footing has been paramount to building shareholder value in today's oil price environment. We intend to emerge as a better, stronger and more profitable company when commodity prices recover. And lastly, we are very fortunate to have an asset that can deliver both strong returns and growth in a low oil price environment. The Anadarko Basin offers strong returns today, and we know that development economics will be significantly better tomorrow. We are highly encouraged with the results we are seeing today in the Anadarko Basin. There is a comprehensive update in today's @NFX publication. You will see that our teams continue to advance learnings to deliver superior well results, optimize completions and improve returns. It's important to note that for the first time, our net daily production from the Anadarko Basin has now eclipsed the combined production from the remainder of our domestic assets. This is quite a milestone considering that the SCOOP and STACK plays literally started from scratch just 4 years ago. Due to the strong growth in the Anadarko Basin and our efforts to maximize base production across the company, we, today, raised our full year expectations for 2015 production, and we will enter 2016 with strong operational momentum. In STACK, we have now drilled nearly 70 wells and have seen strong well results across our acreage. With each well, we gain increased confidence in the play, although the primary focus of our STACK drilling program is the HBP our acreage, we are learning about well spacing, both on the surface and sub-surface, and we will be ready to enter full field development in 2017. Our growing Anadarko Basin assets provide us with a deep inventory of high-return drilling locations that will lead Newfield's growth and profitability for many years to come. Other critical 2015 initiatives relate to our efforts to improve margins across the company. We have worked to significantly improve our cost structure. These gains have many contributors, including high-graded capital investments; reduced service costs; innovative efforts to lower LOE; redeployment of our people; and the rightsizing of our workforce. Our estimated 2015 lease operating expenses on a unit of production basis are expected to be nearly 25% below 2014 levels. We're expecting that LOE will be down an additional 5% to 10% from current levels in 2016. Our 2015 estimated net G&A expense will be down about $25 million over 2014 levels, adjusted for onetime reorganization costs. Our 2016 G&A expense is expected to be down $40 million from this year's level.
In addition, our future realized prices are expected to improve in STACK through better oil price differentials. We're seeing great demand for our STACK barrels today due to both API gravity, crude quality and geographic location.
Before covering our financial results for the third quarter, let me make a few preliminary comments about 2016 and how we are seeing our business plan taking shape. We're running multiple scenarios in preparation for 2016. Although fluid, I can share with you some of the bookends around our analysis. First, we're working toward a capital budget that substantially balances with our expectations for cash flow, inclusive of hedge revenues. As we've said repeatedly, our primary focus today is on maintaining liquidity and a strong balance sheet. We expect to enter 2016 with ample capacity under our $1.8 billion credit facility. This is an investment-grade facility with no redetermination concerns. It's term was extended earlier this year out to 2020. We estimate that our maintenance capital funding level is around $900 million, nearly $800 million would be associated with drilling and completions and the remainder would be allocated to infrastructure, leasehold and land renewals. At today's strip prices, our 2016 hedges should add about $260 million in revenues.
This year, Anadarko Basin volumes will be up nearly 50% over 2014 levels. We enter 2016 with momentum and expect that the continuing growth of SCOOP and STACK in 2016 will more than offset the natural declines in our other domestic areas that are not receiving capital investments today. Our production throughout 2016 is expected to be relatively flat throughout the course of the year should we undertake maintenance capital investment levels. This will put us in a great position to accelerate, and again focus on strong growth once the commodity prices provide the appropriate catalysts. We plan to issue our final 2016 capital budget and guidance along with our fourth quarter and year-end earnings in February of 2016. We are confident in our plan's ability to maintain a strong balance sheet, generate lower operating cost, improve our returns and advance STACK toward full field development in 2017.
Let me quickly cover our financial results for the third quarter. Increasing volumes, coupled with improved costs in the unit production basis define the quarter's highlights. Margin improvements were evident in our cash operating cost. On a unit of production basis, LOE was 15% below our guidance for the quarter and nearly 25% below the comparable period in 2014. G&A expense, excluding onetime costs associated with our reduction in force, and restructuring cost was about $3 million less than guidance. Our capital investment budget for the year remains approximately $1.4 billion and includes capital invested year-to-date to acquire additional land and leasehold in the Anadarko Basin. Through the first 9 months of this year, we sold $77 million of nonstrategic assets as we continue to refine our portfolio and high-grade investments. Year-to-date we've invested about $1.1 billion, excluding capitalized interest and internal cost. There is a helpful table on Page 4 in @NFX that outlets capital investments by quarter, which includes our change in accruals. In terms of production, we extended a healthy streak of beating our projections through solid execution and improving well performance. Our domestic production in the third quarter exceeded our guidance midpoint by 400,000 barrels led by the Anadarko Basin. For the third quarter, our production in the Anadarko Basin came in about 2,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day ahead of our forecast, split equally among our 3 primary commodity products. Total production in the third quarter was 14.3 million of oil equivalent, of which 63% was liquids. Our consolidated oil production during the quarter was 42% higher than the same period as 2014, adjusted for asset sales.
Domestic production was up 10% year-over-year, adjusted for asset sales. Domestic production grew 3% quarter-over-quarter to 12.9 million barrels of oil equivalent. We lifted about 1.4 million barrels to China during the quarter, surpassing our guidance by the about 125,000 barrels. Due to our production outperformance year-to-date, we are, again, raising our annual forecast. Our full year company guidance is now 55.3 million to 55.8 million barrels of oil equivalent. Our domestic production is now expected to be 50.0 million to 50.5 million barrels of oil equivalent. Discretionary cash flow from operations was $280 million or $1.72 per share. Discretionary cash flows were $0.02 light to consensus, primarily due to divesting or payout of previously expensed cash settled restricted stock in the third quarter as well as severance and other reorganization costs. Adjusted net income for the quarter, which excludes several onetime items detailed in our release, was $0.21 per share. The most significant item was a noncash ceiling test right now related to the significant drop in oil prices. As a full-cost company, this charge was certainly expected and was in line with our recent disclosures in our Form 10-Q. This is a noncash charge and has no impact on our credit facility or debt covenants. These impairments are a function of full-cost accounting and significantly lower commodity prices in a 12-month trailing average. Let's move on to our operations update. I'll spend the rest of today on the Anadarko Basin. We're excited about our recent results, which demonstrate material gains in several important areas. First, improving well performance. You can see from today's results that our production from the Anadarko Basin is tracking well above expectations. Today, we raised expectations for our fourth quarter average daily rate from the Anadarko Basin to about 74,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. That's 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day ahead of our beginning of year estimate and 3,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, higher than our estimate last quarter. Second, we're seeing continued gains in drilling efficiencies, which are leading towards lower well cost. In our STACK play, our estimate of well cost at the beginning of the year was $8.5 million. Today, we're drilling and completing wells for $7.5 million or less. Our days to depth are averaging about 16 days and our best-in-class wells are drilled in 12 days. Third, we're effectively optimizing completions. We're making material advancements in our completions, and early results are very promising. And lastly, we're planning for future development. We have a marketing agreements now in place for both oil and gas takeaway in STACK, and we are developing an extensive network to allow for the distribution, recycling and reuse of our frac flowback water. This will be advantageous as we enter full-field development. 
Let's talk about each of these gains starting with the improved well performance. In @NFX, we released results from 22 new SXL wells. We now have 68 wells in our STACK data set and the results have been very consistent across an area that covers more than 1,500 square miles and spans more than 50 miles from corner to corner. In fact, there's a tighter correlation in our STACK results than any of the resource plays we've been associated with to date. Our most recent wells have higher 30- and 60-day rates and not all of the wells have yet reached 90-day production rates. Average a 30-day rates from our 22 new wells exceeded last quarter's wells by 100 barrels of oil equivalent per day. On a wellhead basis, the oil percentage from our new wells average nearly 80% over the first 30 days of production. By the end of this year, we expect to have drilled about 100 STACK wells. This is a very significant data set and is providing us with high confidence in our future forecast. SCOOP is in full development and pad drilling is generating strong returns. Our recent Williams 5-well pad came on at about 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day gross, of which 70% was oil on a 2-stream basis. We had 2 additional SCOOP pads that will begin production shortly and help push our average net production from the Anadarko Basin to about 74,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the fourth quarter. We continue to lower well costs in STACK through innovative bit designs, mud and motor optimizations and the targeting of the most effective drilling zones within the Meramec and Woodford. Today, well costs are about $7.5 million, but more importantly, we can see the path to significantly lower well costs once we move to pad drilling in full field development. We estimate that more than half of the cost savings seen to date is related to efficiencies and fuel optimizations and not simply a result of lower service cost. From our participation in outside operator wells, we know we are leading industry in drilling days and costs. Perhaps, our most significant developments to date are coming through recent completion optimizations. Recall that our first 26 STACK wells have identical completions. We felt early that it was critical to have a large, consistent sample set across our acreage footprint. In 2015, we began to optimize completions in both SCOOP and STACK, adjusting different variables to find the optimal well for full field development. Recent variables explore the use of zipper fracs, diverting agents, high concentrations of fluids and proppants and slip water fracs. We're very encouraged by the early performance results from these optimizations. Within a larger sample set in time, we will know the magnitude of the impact on our EURs and rates of return. Stay tuned, we'll have more to share with you in the way of data very soon. 
We recently signed new agreements that will help ensure that we have good markets in the possible differentials for our growing STACK production. As today, our STACK oil is trucked to Cushing, Oklahoma. Under our new agreements, we will begin piping about 1/3 of our STACK production in January of 2016 and by the end of the second quarter, 100% of our STACK oil will be piped into Cushing. We've seen a growing appetite for our STACK barrel, which is a 42- to 45-degree API barrel. We will soon have the ability to batch our oil to ensure the best price. We expect our differential to NYMEX WTI will decrease from about $4.50 per barrel today to about $2.50 per barrel early next year. As you can tell in our remarks today, we are very encouraged with the continuing progress that we're making in the Anadarko Basin. And we'll be happy to discussed additional details during our Q&A. 
So in closing, I'd like to say Newfield is in a very good place today. We didn't arrive here by chance. We took the right steps 12 to 18 months ago and hedged forward oil sales to ensure our cash flow. We upsized and extended our credit facility through 2020, ensuring our liquidity position and eliminating redetermination risk, and we sold $2.5 billion in assets at yesterday's commodity prices. These strategic decisions were timely and help with Newfield in an advantaged position today despite a very challenging microenvironment. We are fortunate that we can provide our shareholders with both volumes and value. Growth in shareholder value creation are not mutually exclusive regardless of where we find ourselves in the inevitable commodity price cycles. Thanks for your investment in our company, and we look forward to taking your questions. Operator?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Richard Tullis from Capital One.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we saw a nice uptick in the STACK well productivity. When you take a look at the latest SCOOP oil wells with the 90-day oil production, it looks like there was a bit of a drop in the percentage oil. My calculation's like 42% versus 51% from the earlier
componenttext: So we saw a nice uptick in the STACK well productivity. When you take a look at the latest SCOOP oil wells with the 90-day oil production, it looks like there was a bit of a drop in the percentage oil. My calculation's like 42% versus 51% from the earlier results. I might be off a little bit. But what was the main driver for those declines?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's important when you look at the Anadarko Basin and SCOOP and STACK, and I'll get to the specifics of your question in a moment. So remember that we're drilling across various positions within phase envelopes. So you're going to see a natu
componenttext: Yes. I think it's important when you look at the Anadarko Basin and SCOOP and STACK, and I'll get to the specifics of your question in a moment. So remember that we're drilling across various positions within phase envelopes. So you're going to see a natural variation across the play. We've got plenty of data. We know where we are in the phase envelopes, so we know what the expectations are, but from quarter-to-quarter or data set to data set, you'll have pad wells coming into play. And as we move towards the development, you'll have both the noise that comes in from OBO activity as well, but small variations, a few percentage points, one way or the other, are nothing could be concerned about. So what I would tell you, in the SCOOP wells down there, we have -- the 5-well pad that was referenced, we're very, very pleased with the results and they're in line with our expectations in the play. And the same is true with regard to STACK. I can't think of the last time we had any surprises with regard to phase composition and production types in this play. We've got plenty of data, and it's pretty well-defined at this stage.

componenttext: I know you've outlined a path to balance CapEx and cash flows in 2016 while keeping domestic production flat. I was hoping you could provide some just early color on what production allocation may look like between the SCOOP oil, SCOOP condensate, SCOOP Springer and the STACK?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I've said carefully that we're going to come up with our final guidance which will include an update on the portfolio, well count locations and 2016 mix in February '16. We're going to stick to that schedule. The commentary on maintenance capital is
componenttext: Well, I've said carefully that we're going to come up with our final guidance which will include an update on the portfolio, well count locations and 2016 mix in February '16. We're going to stick to that schedule. The commentary on maintenance capital is to give you a reference point that we've said pretty consistently on the road since earlier this year that in a $50 and below world that you can probably expect Newfield to execute a balanced plan. We're presently in a $50-ish world. When you think about it in this regard, so we're thinking that's more likely or not, we'll have a balanced program going into 2016. Put ourselves in a position to time the recovery, if you will, and the commodity and step on the accelerator at the right time, but balanced program is the right place to go, and it will be Anadarko-centric. We'll have to finish our HBP drilling, which should be a large part of our activity in 2016. And then once we move into the full field development stage in STACK, initially 2017 forward, you'll have a more consistent forecast from that point forward.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And do you have any planned noncore asset divestitures that you may use to fund full-field development maybe in 2017 or just add to liquidity or -- and improve the balance sheet?
componenttext: Okay. And do you have any planned noncore asset divestitures that you may use to fund full-field development maybe in 2017 or just add to liquidity or -- and improve the balance sheet?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been careful to say that -- and I think we've demonstrated with $2.5 billion of asset sales that funded our transformation, every asset has a life cycle. So over the course of time, it's not a question of if, it's when. And clearly, we do have
componenttext: Well, we've been careful to say that -- and I think we've demonstrated with $2.5 billion of asset sales that funded our transformation, every asset has a life cycle. So over the course of time, it's not a question of if, it's when. And clearly, we do have other assets in the portfolio we could consider for divestment. The specific answer to your question, we have nothing, no planed sales at this point in time. We do have assets that would be considered for this position at the right place and time when we choose to accelerate activity in the Anadarko Basin. So the answer to that is yes, not today.

componenttext: Leo, I think the other thing to remember when you look at overall data set as we approach 70 odd wells, through the course of the drilling, we've got about 2/3 of the total test in the Meramec and about 1/3 in the Woodford, if I remember. I think those are the numbers that we've put out previously. Obviously, as we move around HBP and there will be places where we test the Meramec in places where we're testing Woodford, but it's been roughly pretty consistent around 2/3, 1/3 over that time period, last 4 years.

componenttext: All right, that's helpful. I just wanted to qualify the one comment that you made, Lee. You talked about that theoretical maintenance CapEx of $900 million in flattish production. Is that flat year-over-year in '16 versus full year '15? Or was that flat with fourth quarter of '15?

componenttext: It would be flat year-over-year when we're talking about maintenance capital, but I would say that with the scenarios that we're running at this point in time, we would expect quarter-to-quarter in that regime to be pretty flat all the way through the year.

componenttext: Yes, I would say that China is producing in line with our expectations. It's a function of timing of liftings. componenttext: Well, I think it's -- look, we've got competitive advantages and strong position and we're going to compete for every acre that makes sense. Certainly, we understand the play, and we've got a good, strong position, and we'll look to add to it opportunistically when those opportunities present themselves.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the significant improvement you're showing quarter-over-quarter on STACK wells, to the extent that you can, what's the biggest reason for these wells? Is it just drilling completion techniques? Or is it something in the acreage that you're
componenttext: Just looking at the significant improvement you're showing quarter-over-quarter on STACK wells, to the extent that you can, what's the biggest reason for these wells? Is it just drilling completion techniques? Or is it something in the acreage that you're going and drilling at various portions?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that I've listed a whole smattering of things that we're testing, and I guess the first thing I would tell you is remember that we're relatively early in this data set. Not all of the wells have made it to 90 days, so we have good 30- an
componenttext: Well, I would say that I've listed a whole smattering of things that we're testing, and I guess the first thing I would tell you is remember that we're relatively early in this data set. Not all of the wells have made it to 90 days, so we have good 30- and 60-day data. The focus is on optimizing completions and we've kind of got a menu, it's sort of an all of the above things that makes sense. I listed diverters. We've previously talked about reductions in cluster spacing on the perfs. Targeting, where do you target within the various horizons for the best completions. It's a combination of a lot of factors, but I think the follow-on point that you're probably wanting to ask is, when do you see this translate through the EUR. We'll give you our updates on our thoughts on the EUR when we come up with our 2016 plan but, clearly, 100 barrel oil equivalent per day increase in the average, quarter-over-quarter, 1,000 barrels a day-type, 30-day IPs, we're excited about it. I think that's a key takeaway.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then when you talk about'16, when you talk about maintenance capital, there's not a goal, I believe, of achieving HBP in the STACK. Is that possible by year-end '16 with the maintenance capital? Or do you need to push it to '17?
componenttext: Great. And then when you talk about'16, when you talk about maintenance capital, there's not a goal, I believe, of achieving HBP in the STACK. Is that possible by year-end '16 with the maintenance capital? Or do you need to push it to '17?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that what we said earlier this year is that we were going to stay aggressively focused on HBP-ing our STACK acreage as that was kind of our pressing need. Now we're fortunate that we have high return wells that we're drilling, we're not in d
componenttext: Well, I think that what we said earlier this year is that we were going to stay aggressively focused on HBP-ing our STACK acreage as that was kind of our pressing need. Now we're fortunate that we have high return wells that we're drilling, we're not in development mode so typically, we'll drill a 10,000-foot well, and we'll protect 2 sections and then we'll move about 2 miles away and we'll drill the next 2 sections. So it's a lot of work. We'll be at about 100 wells by the end of this year. We'll need to touch over 200 wells to get the core footprint HBP. So it tells you that there'll be a lot of drilling, the rig count is shifting in favor of STACK. That's been happening during the course of the year. I would guess that at a level of funding that you talked about, $900 million-, $1 billion-type funding, somewhere in that zip code, we'll be 90%-plus HBP by the end of the year and we'll finish up the HBP early in 2017.

componenttext: The STACK wells continue to show improvements in productivity whether you measure it in absolute terms or on a per foot of lateral basis. What should we expect in terms of the rate of change going forward, given the completion optimization, operations under way today?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the shortest answer is that it's still early innings. I think there's a lot going on, a lot that we're doing, a lot that other competitors in the play are doing. I think we're all learning from each other. Clearly, I would expect to see
componenttext: Well, I think that the shortest answer is that it's still early innings. I think there's a lot going on, a lot that we're doing, a lot that other competitors in the play are doing. I think we're all learning from each other. Clearly, I would expect to see some continued learning and positive results related thereto. But the pace, the actual rate of that change, I'm not going to try to answer that today, I just think that we're still early innings and there'll be some more wins before this is over with.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our discussion from Dan Guffey with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll take our discussion from Dan Guffey with Stifel.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to dive in a little bit more on spacing. I know you mentioned you're done with spacing tests for this year. Just curious, your thoughts on if 880 feet or 6 wells per section is the right spacing. And then also, on your third and fourth test th
componenttext: Just wanted to dive in a little bit more on spacing. I know you mentioned you're done with spacing tests for this year. Just curious, your thoughts on if 880 feet or 6 wells per section is the right spacing. And then also, on your third and fourth test that you guys did or, I guess, your third specifically as you were previously defining it, you had 2 in the Meramec that were stacked and staggered, vertical spacing was around 175 feet, are you seeing any degradation or communication that's pushing down or pulling down some of those production rates from those pilots? Or are all of them, essentially, at or above your type curves?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me -- I'll start with the kind of high-level commentary. I don't know that we said that we weren't doing anymore pilot tests between now and year end. I think that we'll have ongoing well pairs, 2 well pairs. We have no specific multi-wells fa
componenttext: Yes. So let me -- I'll start with the kind of high-level commentary. I don't know that we said that we weren't doing anymore pilot tests between now and year end. I think that we'll have ongoing well pairs, 2 well pairs. We have no specific multi-wells facing -- pilots being drilled. But we do continue -- we do plan to continue to drill 2 well pairs where we can across the acreage footprint, just to make sense, so you can gather the information. I think the results that we've seen from all of the wells that we've released to date have been in line or above the published type curves, so we've been very pleased there. We've not seen any negative interference effects or degradation. So another thing to be very pleased with. The closest we've been able to get is 880 feet, I believe. And the reason for that is when you drill across lease lines, the State of Oklahoma rules, that's as close as we can get. So practically speaking, that's about 6 wells per horizon, if you wanted to think about it at that level. I think we feel pretty comfortable with the results we're seeing there. We'll have to wait for the mood to shift into development to drill multi-well pilots, and I'm sure we'll test spacing tighter than that once we get there. But right now, we're very encouraged with the results. We'll continue to add to the data set. When we get the acreage footprint, HBP, that's going to be a pretty fantastic place to be. Because we will have all of that spacing and well-performance data before we ever actually get into the development mode, that's a luxury we haven't had in any of the previous plays.

componenttext: Okay, great. So it sounds like the data of what you gathered this year, the inventory number that you provided at the beginning of the year, this year, should -- the inventory in STACK should significantly increase when you put your numbers out in February of '16. Is that correct?

componenttext: Well, I think we're very encouraged. We'll update the inventory and the well counts and give you that information as part of our year-end data set, consistent with what we've been doing the last 2 or 3 years.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then again, on optimizations. I know you said you're kind of -- it's a full menu of trying out many different types. I guess, how close do you guys feel like you are to reaching optimization? And do you think all of '16 will get you to where you need to be when you're in your full field development mode and actually have a recipe that you consistently used?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would tell you that we'll continue to learn as we move through the development of this play. I would expect to see continued improvements, as we said earlier. I think the key to remember is our team starts at time 0 in these plays, not to chase press
componenttext: So I would tell you that we'll continue to learn as we move through the development of this play. I would expect to see continued improvements, as we said earlier. I think the key to remember is our team starts at time 0 in these plays, not to chase press releases and big IPs, but to design the development well. So we're working on the development well designs today. We want compact, tight, complex fraction networks, and that's really what the focus is. I would take you back, I don't know if we've talked, Dan, but I'm sure you've heard Steve and others and some of the materials we've put out. I love looking at what the team's accomplished in the Williston Basin. And we're drilling and completing 21,000-, 22,000-foot wells there today for $5 million, including facilities. And those wells are virtually identical to the types of wells that we'll be drilling in STACK. So we get to development mode, I wouldn't bet against team Newfield.

componenttext: We've seen other operators, you're meeting your oil volume -- meeting or exceeding your oil volumes and then getting an uplift of incremental gas and NGLs that are kind of gratis or gravy on your economics. Just trying to get an idea of -- oil's making it, but does gas and NGL even beat more and give you some more juice?

componenttext: Yes. Well, I think that the politest answer I can give today is let us accumulate some more time on the wells that we've released today. We're going to add additional wells in the course of the fourth quarter. So we'll go into next year with 100 wells in our data set. So the data set's growing at a pretty rapid pace in that regard. Clearly, with the uplift that you're seeing early, on the early returns on these wells, my expectation is that it will ultimately translate to an uptick in EUR so you'll see improvement across the product mix: oil, NGLs and gas.

componenttext: So the Anadarko Basin production has obviously increased as a percentage of total domestic volumes. componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll stick to the same comment. We'll give you the '16 absolute figures when we come out in February with that data. The trend line, I think you're onto a good line of reasoning, I think the Anadarko is going to become a more dominant part of the
componenttext:
Yes. So I'll stick to the same comment. We'll give you the '16 absolute figures when we come out in February with that data. The trend line, I think you're onto a good line of reasoning, I think the Anadarko is going to become a more dominant part of the portfolio. We mentioned in the call that we've gone past 50% and, clearly, the margins are improving there. So the Anadarko Basin, the economic draw, the gravitational pull we've been talking about the last 2 or 3 years just continues to get stronger and stronger. It will translate to materially improved margins, 2016 forward. We kind of like that.
Well, I guess -- I think that was the last call. So we'll go ahead and thank everybody for tuning in this morning. I appreciate the questions. We look forward to updating you on the full year 2015 results and our 2016 plan going forward. And again, thanks for your interest and investment in Newfield. Have a good day.
